á¼ˆÎ˜á¿‹ÎÎ‘
á¼€Îµá½¶ Î¼á½³Î½, á½¦ Ï€Î±á¿– Î›Î±ÏÏ„á½·Î¿Ï…, Î´á½³Î´Î¿ÏÎºá½± ÏƒÎµ ğŸ—©
Line 1

Among the plays of Sophocles there were many, as titles and fragments show, of which the scene was laid at Troy, and of which the action was founded on the epics of the Trojan cycle. This series ranged over the whole course of the ten years' war, from its earliest incidents, as told in the Cypria, down to the fall of the city, as told in the Iliupersis. The Philoctetes is connected with this series, but the Ajax is the only remaining piece which actually belongs to it. The story is taken from sources later than the Iliad, but the conception of the hero, though modified by that later legend, is fundamentally Homeric.

In the Iliad, Ajax, the son of Telamon, comes to Troy The Ajax of the Iliad. from Salamis with twelve ships, and is stationed on the extreme left of the army, at the east end of the camp,â€”as Achilles holds the corresponding post of honour on the rightIl. 11. 7â€”9.. He is an independent chief,â€”subject only to the allegiance which all the chiefs owe to the Captain General, Agamemnon. There is no reference to his descent from Aeacus; nor is there anything that connects him especially with AthensIn the Catalogue only two verses are given to Ajax, Il. 2. 557 f.:â€” Î‘á¼´Î±Ï‚ Î´â€™ á¼Îº Î£Î±Î»Î±Î¼á¿–Î½Î¿Ï‚ á¼„Î³ÎµÎ½ Î´Ï…Î¿ÎºÎ±á½·Î´ÎµÎºÎ± Î½á¿†Î±Ï‚Â· ÏƒÏ„á¿†ÏƒÎµ Î´â€™ á¼„Î³Ï‰Î½ á¼µÎ½â€™ á¼ˆÎ¸Î·Î½Î±á½·Ï‰Î½ á¼µÏƒÏ„Î±Î½Ï„Î¿ Ï†á½±Î»Î±Î³Î³ÎµÏ‚. The second verse is absent from our best MSS., as it was from some of the editions known to Quintilian (5. 11 Â§ 40). Aristotle (Rhet. I. 15 Â§ 13) alludes to it as having been quoted by the Athenians in support of their claim to Salamis, and the interpolation must be at least as old as the date of their controversy with the Megarians (circ. 600â€”595 B.C.), whether the author was Solon or not. The Alexandrian critics rejected the verse, pointing out that Ajax, on the extreme left, had the Thessalians for his neighbours on the right ( Il. 13. 681), while Odysseus, at the middle of the camp, was next to the Athenians ( Il. 4. 329): Strabo 9. p. 394. Verse 557 may have been interpolated along with v. 558. If, however, it belonged to the genuine text, it must originally have been followed by more than one verse relating to Ajax, who was too important to be dismissed so curtly.. He has a well-recognised rank as being, next to Achilles, the greatest warrior in the Greek armyIl. 2. 768 á¼€Î½Î´Ïá¿¶Î½ Î±á½– Î¼á½³Î³â€™ á¼„ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚ á¼”Î·Î½ Î¤ÎµÎ»Î±Î¼á½½Î½Î¹Î¿Ï‚ Î‘á¼´Î±Ï‚ á½„Ï†Ïâ€™ á¼ˆÏ‡Î¹Î»Îµá½ºÏ‚ Î¼á½µÎ½Î¹ÎµÎ½. He holds the same rank in the Odyssey (11. 468); with Alcaeus (fr. 48 Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼„ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½ Ï€ÎµÎ´â€™ á¼ˆÏ‡á½·Î»Î»ÎµÎ±); with Pindar (N. 7. 27 ÎºÏá½±Ï„Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½ á¼ˆÏ‡Î¹Î»á½³Î¿Ï‚ á¼„Ï„ÎµÏ); with Sophocles ( Ai. 1340); and in later literature (Hor. S. 2. 3. 193heros ab Achille secundus; Philostratus Heroic. 719 f.; Dictys 4. 5, etc.).. Gigantic in statureâ€”taller by a head and shoulders than his fellowsâ€”and of a massive frame, he is emphatically the â€˜bulwarkâ€™ of the Greek host Il. 3. 227á¼”Î¾Î¿Ï‡Î¿Ï‚ á¼ˆÏÎ³Îµá½·Ï‰Î½ ÎºÎµÏ†Î±Î»á½µÎ½ Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Îµá½Ïá½³Î±Ï‚ á½¤Î¼Î¿Ï…Ï‚: 229 Ï€ÎµÎ»á½½ÏÎ¹Î¿Ï‚, á¼•ÏÎºÎ¿Ï‚ á¼ˆÏ‡Î±Î¹á¿¶Î½.. In comeliness, too, he is second only to the son of Peleus Il. 17. 279.; but â€˜huge Aresâ€™ is the god to whom he is compared; and when he is described â€˜with a smile on his grim face,â€™ it is in the joy of battle Il. 7. 208ÏƒÎµá½»Î±Ï„â€™ á¼”Ï€ÎµÎ¹Î¸â€™ Î¿á¼·á½¹Ï‚ Ï„Îµ Ï€ÎµÎ»á½½ÏÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ á¼”ÏÏ‡ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ á¼ŒÏÎ·Ï‚: 212 Î¼ÎµÎ¹Î´Î¹á½¹Ï‰Î½ Î²Î»Î¿ÏƒÏ…ÏÎ¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹ Ï€ÏÎ¿Ïƒá½½Ï€Î±ÏƒÎ¹.. The Homeric poet illustrates the qualities of his valourâ€”both impetuous and obstinateâ€”by likening him, first, to a lion in his onset, and then, when he is forced back by superior numbers, to a stubborn ass, whom boys, with feeble but incessant blows, laboriously cudgel out of a cornfield Il. 11. 548-562.. Staunch and steadfast, he never fails his friends at need â€”whether it be some individual comrade, such as his half-brother Teucer, whom he protects Il. 8. 266, etc., or whether he comes to the rescue of the whole army at some crisisAs in the battle at the ships, when he wounds Hector ( Il. 14. 409 ff.); or in the fight over the body of Patroclus (17. 281 ff.).. In the absence of Achilles, it is only Ajax who is a match for HectorThe Greek chiefs rejoice when it falls to the lot of Ajax to meet Hector in single combat ( Il. 7. 182).. The sevenfold shieldMade of seven layers of bull's hide, with a layer of metal nailed on the top,â€” Ï‡á¼Î»ÎºÎµÎ¿Î½, á¼‘Ï€Ï„Î±Î²á½¹ÎµÎ¹Î¿Î½â€”as described in Il. 7. 219-223. of Ajax is not only his characteristic attribute, but the symbol of his service,â€”great in attack, but especially signal in defence: and as the mighty shield is compared in the Iliad to a tower, so its owner himself is elsewhere called â€˜a tower of strengthâ€™ to the Achaeans Il. 7. 219Ï†á½³ÏÏ‰Î½ Ïƒá½±ÎºÎ¿Ï‚ á¼ á¿£Ï„Îµ Ï€á½»ÏÎ³Î¿Î½: Od. 11. 556 (Î¿Ï† Î±jÎ±Ï‡) Ï„Î¿á¿–Î¿Ï‚ Î³á½±Ï ÏƒÏ†Î¹Î½ Ï€á½»ÏÎ³Î¿Ï‚ á¼€Ï€á½½Î»ÎµÎ¿..

The Athena of Sophocles speaks of Ajax as pre-eminent not only for bravery but for prudencev. 119 Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Î¿Ï… Ï„á½·Ï‚ á¼„Î½ ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ Ï„á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼¢ Ï€ÏÎ¿Î½Î¿á½»ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏÎ¿Ï‚, á¼¢ Î´Ïá¾¶Î½ á¼€Î¼Îµá½·Î½Ï‰Î½ Î·á½‘Ïá½³Î¸Î· Ï„á½° ÎºÎ±á½·ÏÎ¹Î±;. This is true to the picture of him in the Iliad. Once, indeed, after he has uttered a defiant and menacing challenge, Hector calls him â€˜a blunderer, a clumsy braggart Il. 13. 824Î‘á¼¶Î±Î½ á¼Î¼Î±ÏÏ„Î¿ÎµÏ€á½³Ï‚, Î²Î¿Ï…Î³á½±ÏŠÎµ.â€™; as, in Shakespeare, Thersites calls him a â€˜beef-witted lord,â€™ and Ulysses, â€˜the lubber AjaxTroilus and Cressida, 2. 1. 12, 3. 3. 139..â€™ In another place, however,â€”when he agrees, at the herald's suggestion, to break off his combat with Hector, though he was having the best of it,â€”his chivalrous opponent recognises Ajax as one to whom the gods have given, not only â€˜stature and might,â€™ but â€˜understanding Il. 7. 288Î‘á¼¶Î±Î½, á¼Ï€Îµá½· Ï„Î¿Î¹ Î´á¿¶ÎºÎµ Î¸Îµá½¸Ï‚ Î¼á½³Î³ÎµÎ¸á½¹Ï‚ Ï„Îµ Î²á½·Î·Î½ Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€Î¹Î½Ï…Ï„á½µÎ½..â€™ His good sense is conspicuous in the embassy to Achilles, where he is the colleague of Odysseus and Phoenix. It is he who perceives when the moment has come for ceasing to press the inexorable hero. â€˜Let us go hence; for I do not think that the end of our message can be gained by this mission.â€™ He points out to his companions that it seems hopeless to move Achilles at present: and then, turning to Achilles himself, he addresses him in words of frank reproach, but also of friendly appeal and of cordial good-will Il. 9. 624-642..

One trait, however, marks an important difference between the Homeric and the later conception. In the play of Sophocles Ajax appears as one who has offended Athena by the presumptuous self-confidence with which he has rejected divine aid in war. There is no trace of this in the Iliad. While he is arming for the combat with Hector, he exhorts the Greeks to pray that Zeus may help him Il. 7. 193 ff.. In the battle at the ships, after splendid deeds of valour, he retreats when he perceives, with a thrill of awe, that, for the time, the gods are against him Il. 16. 119Î³Î½á¿¶ Î´â€™ Î‘á¼´Î±Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° Î¸Ï…Î¼á½¸Î½ á¼€Î¼á½»Î¼Î¿Î½Î± á¿¥á½·Î³Î·Ïƒá½³Î½ Ï„Îµ á¼”ÏÎ³Î± Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½.. During the battle over the body of Patroclus, when a thick mist has fallen on the field, his prayer for light breathes reverent submission to the will of Zeus Il. 17. 645 ff..

Such is the Ajax of the Iliad; a mighty champion of the Greeks in their sorest need; a man of good sense and good feeling, sparing of words, but able to speak wisely in season; loyal to his friends; straightforward and unselfish; frankly conscious of his strength, but placing his reliance on the help of the gods, and yielding, even in the fiercest struggle, to revelations of their mind.

A contest between Ajax and Odysseus for the arms of Achilles, resulting in the defeat and suicide of Ajax, is first mentioned in the Odyssey Od. 11. 543-547: Î¿á¼´Î· Î´â€™ Î‘á¼´Î±Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ ÏˆÏ…Ï‡á½´ Î¤ÎµÎ»Î±Î¼Ï‰Î½Î¹á½±Î´Î±Î¿ Î½á½¹ÏƒÏ†Î¹Î½ á¼€Ï†ÎµÏƒÏ„á½µÎºÎµÎ¹, ÎºÎµÏ‡Î¿Î»Ï‰Î¼á½³Î½Î· Îµá¼µÎ½ÎµÎºÎ± Î½á½·ÎºÎ·Ï‚ Ï„á½µÎ½ Î¼Î¹Î½ á¼Î³á½¼ Î½á½·ÎºÎ·ÏƒÎ± Î´Î¹ÎºÎ±Î¶á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ Ï€Î±Ïá½° Î½á¿ƒÏ…Ïƒá½¶ Ï„Îµá½»Ï‡ÎµÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼€Î¼Ï†â€™ á¼ˆÏ‡Î¹Î»á¿†Î¿Ï‚Â· á¼”Î¸Î·ÎºÎµ Î´á½² Ï€á½¹Ï„Î½Î¹Î± Î¼á½µÏ„Î·Ï, Ï€Î±á¿–Î´ÎµÏ‚ Î´á½² Î¤Ïá½½Ï‰Î½ Î´á½·ÎºÎ±ÏƒÎ±Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î Î±Î»Î»á½°Ï‚ á¼ˆÎ¸á½µÎ½Î·. On the last verse (547) the schol. (H) says, á¼€Î¸ÎµÏ„Îµá¿– á¼ˆÏá½·ÏƒÏ„Î±ÏÏ‡Î¿Ï‚. It is not known on what grounds he rejected it; whether because the verse was absent from some copies; or because it conflicted with some other version of the matter which he regarded as having better authority; or for both reasons. The context itself affords no reason for suspecting this particular verse; on the contrary, the mention of the person who proposed the prize (á¼”Î¸Î·ÎºÎµ) is most naturally followed by a mention of the persons who made the award; and the passage would be maimed by the omission. W. Christ holds that Aristarchus was mistaken in condemning verse 547, and that it represents an early version of the story, probably that given by ArctÃ®nus in the Aethiopis (Jahr. f. Philol. 1881 p. 444): see also Kirchhoff (Hom. Odyss. p. 231); and K. F. Ameis ad loc. The whole passage relating to the contest of the arms may, no doubt, be later than other parts of the Îá½³ÎºÏ…Î¹Î±., where the sullen shade of the injured hero refuses to hold converse with the victor. It was the goddess Thetis who set her son's arms for a prize; â€˜the judges were the children of the Trojans and Pallas Athena.â€™

Ï€Îµá¿–Ïá½±Î½ Ï„Î¹Î½â€™ á¼Ï‡Î¸Ïá¿¶Î½ á¼ÏÏ€á½±ÏƒÎ±Î¹ Î¸Î·Ïá½½Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½Â· ğŸ—©

The whole passage Cyclic epics. The Aethiopis. evidently presupposes some well-known work or works in which the contest for the arms had been related more at length. The scholiast says that â€˜the story comes from the Cyclic poetsSchol. H on Od. 11. 547á¼¡ Î´á½² á¼±ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ïá½·Î± á¼Îº Ï„á¿¶Î½ ÎºÏ…ÎºÎ»Î¹Îºá¿¶Î½..â€™ There are two poems, and two only, which are known to have contained that story. One is the Aethiopis, by ArctÃ®nus of Miletus, which may be placed about 776 B.C. The other is the Little Iliad, which in later antiquity was commonly (though not universally) ascribed to LeschesAs Carl Robert has pointed out in Bild und Lied (â€˜Arktinos und Lesches,â€™ pp. 222 ff.), the claim of Lesches is subject to much doubt. Hellanicus, himself a Lesbian, attributed the Little Iliad to Cinaethon of Lacedaemon, according to the scholiast on Eur. Tro. 821; where Thestorides of Phocis and Diodorus of Erythrae are mentioned as other writers to whom the poem had been attributedâ€”while Lesches is not even named. The scholiast probably derived this statement from the Alexandrian Lysimachus, a learned mythographer, whose work entitled Îá½¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î¹ is often quoted., of Pyrrha, near Mitylene, and of which the approximate date is 700 B.C.

In the Aethiopis, which contained the death of Achilles, Ajax played a foremost part in rescuing the corpse from the Trojansâ€” an episode imitated from the fight over the body of Patroclus in the Iliad. As to the manner in which ArctÃ®nus conceived the contest for the arms, only two details are known. (1) After the award, Podaleiriusâ€”the physician, skilled in diagnosis of obscure ailments, as his brother Machaon was the great surgeonâ€”perceived a fierce light in the eyes of Ajax, and a weight upon his spirit, which were the precursors of the end:â€”

á½…Ï‚ á¿¥Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î‘á¼´Î±Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Ï€Ïá¿¶Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Î¼á½±Î¸Îµ Ï‡Ï‰Î¿Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Î¹Î¿ á½„Î¼Î¼Î±Ï„á½± Ï„â€™ á¼€ÏƒÏ„Ïá½±Ï€Ï„Î¿Î½Ï„Î± Î²Î±ÏÏ…Î½á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½á½¹Î½ Ï„Îµ Î½á½¹Î·Î¼Î±Schol. Il. 11. 515(referring to the skill of Machaon in surgery): Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿ á¼”Î¿Î¹ÎºÎµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼ˆÏÎºÏ„á¿–Î½Î¿Ï‚ á¼Î½ á¼¸Î»á½·Î¿Ï… Ï€Î¿ÏÎ¸á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹ Î½Î¿Î¼á½·Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½ á¼Î½ Î¿á¼·Ï‚ Ï†Î·ÏƒÎ¹Î½ [here he quotes eight verses from ArctÃ®nus, on the skill of Machaon and Podaleirius respectively, ending with the two verses given above]. ArctÃ®nus was the author of two poems: (1) the Î‘á¼°Î¸Î¹Î¿Ï€á½·Ï‚, which ended with the contest between Ajax and Odysseus for the arms: (2) the á¼¸Î»á½·Î¿Ï… Ï€á½³ÏÏƒÎ¹Ï‚, which (like the Little Iliad) probably included the healing of Philoctetes. The scholiast quotes these verses as being á¼Î½ á¼¸Î»á½·Î¿Ï… Ï€Î¿ÏÎ¸á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹. It has been supposed that they occurred in connection with the contest for the arms, and that therefore the scholiast ought to have said á¼Î½ Î‘á¼°Î¸Î¹Î¿Ï€á½·Î´Î¹. But it is also possible that the scholiast is rightâ€”that the verses came from the Iliupersis, and had to do with the healing of Philoctetes. Certainly, as Mr Monro has remarked (Journ. Hellen. Stud. vol. v. p. 29), â€˜the two lines about Ajax have rather the appearance of a parenthesis.â€™ If, however, the skill of Podaleirius was thus illustrated by a glance backward at the insight which he had formerly shown with regard to Ajax, we can scarcely avoid supposing that in the Aethiopis, when the contest for the arms was being related, this observation by Podaleirius had already been mentioned. The parenthesis would be clumsy and out of place, if the fact was being noticed for the first time. Indeed, such an allusion might well suggest the inference that in the Aethiopis the contest for the arms, and the effect of his defeat upon Ajax, were described with some fulness.. (2) ArctÃ®nus described Ajax as killing himself â€˜about dawnSchol. Pind. Isthm. 4.(3.) 58 á½ Î³á½°Ï Ï„á½´Î½ Î‘á¼°Î¸Î¹Î¿Ï€á½·Î´Î± Î³Ïá½±Ï†Ï‰Î½ Ï€ÎµÏá½¶ Ï„á½¸Î½ á½„ÏÎ¸ÏÎ¿Î½ Ï†Î·Ïƒá½¶ Ï„á½¸Î½ Î‘á¼´Î±Î½Ï„Î± á¼‘Î±Ï…Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼€Î½ÎµÎ»Îµá¿–Î½.â€™â€” doubtless on the morning after the award. There is no reason to think that ArctÃ®nus mentioned that delusion of Ajax by Athena which caused his slaughter of the cattle. The scanty evidence rather suggests that the rage in the hero's soul was not expressed in any deed of violence, but that he passed in seclusion, perhaps within his tent, the few hours of darkness between his defeat and his deathWe have just seen that, according to ArctÃ®nus, it was the acute physician Podaleirius who â€˜firstâ€™ detected the symptoms of anger and deep mental trouble in Ajax. This clearly implies that Ajax, though with rage in his soul, retained his self-command. What the physician was â€˜the firstâ€™ to see, others saw only in the light of the tragic eventâ€”the hero's suicide, which so quickly ensued. So, at least, I understand the force of Ï€Ïá¿¶Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Î¼á½±Î¸Îµ. The antithesis might be, of course, with the later perception caused in others by an outbreak of fury on the part of Ajax: but, in connection with the fact that he was here represented as dying almost immediately after the award, this seems less probable.. It is highly probable that the older and simpler form of the Ajax-myth knew nothing of his insane onslaught on the cattle, by which Athena averted his vengeance from the Greek chiefs. The motive of his suicide, in this older version, seems to have been simply resentment at the awardâ€” not that feeling combined with a sense of disgrace incurred by his own action. Such is certainly the impression given by the passage in the Odyssey Od. 11. 543 ff.: not merely because it is silent respecting madness and outrage, but because it implies (556 f.) that Ajax had died, like Achilles, in unclouded renown â€”without having done anything to offend the Greeks, who in the play of Sophocles (v. 726) threaten to stone Teucer, as â€˜the kinsman of the maniac, the plotter against the host.â€™. It is given also by Pindar, when he says, â€˜The Danaoi paid court to Odysseus by secret votes, and Ajax, robbed of the golden arms, wrestled with death Nem. 8. 26 f. Precisely the same impressionâ€”that the suicide was the immediate consequence of the awardâ€”is conveyed in Nem. 7. 25, Î¿á½” ÎºÎµÎ½ á½…Ï€Î»Ï‰Î½ Ï‡Î¿Î»Ï‰Î¸Îµá½¶Ï‚ á½ ÎºÎ±ÏÏ„ÎµÏá½¸Ï‚ Î‘á¼´Î±Ï‚ á¼”Ï€Î±Î¾Îµ Î´Î¹á½° Ï†ÏÎµÎ½á¿¶Î½ Î»ÎµÏ…Ïá½¸Î½ Î¾á½·Ï†Î¿Ï‚. Eustathius (p. 1698. 51), in commenting on Od. 11. 543 ff., thus closes his paraphrase of the account given by some â€˜othersâ€™ (who probably include ArctÃ®nus)â€”ÎºÎ±á½¶ Îµá½Î¸á½ºÏ‚ á½ˆÎ´Ï…ÏƒÏƒÎµá½ºÏ‚ Î¼á½²Î½ á¼”Î»Î±Î²Îµ Ï„á½° á½…Ï€Î»Î±, Î‘á¼´Î±Ï‚ Î´á½² á¼€Ï€á¿†Î»Î¸Îµ [á¼€Ï€á½³Î¸Î±Î½Îµ?] Î¾á½·Ï†ÎµÎ¹ Ï€ÎµÏƒá½½Î½..â€™ Pindar agrees with ArctÃ®nus in saying that Ajax died about dawnâ€”a coincidence which can hardly be accidental Isthm. 3. 53á½€Ïˆá½·á¾³ | á¼Î½ Î½Ï…ÎºÏ„á½·, i.e. â€˜at the end of the night,â€™=Ï€ÎµÏá½¶ á½„ÏÎ¸ÏÎ¿Î½ (see above, note 1)..

There is another point, however, in which it seems probable that they diverged. According to Pindar, the Greek chiefs were the judges in the contest for the arms. This account, which Sophocles follows, is fitted to win sympathy for Ajax, who appears as a victim of jealousy and of ingratitude on the part of men who had the best reason to know that he was second only to Achilles. But the Odyssey testifies to that other version according to which the judges were â€˜the children of the Trojans and Pallas Athena.â€™ The words of the scholiastSchol. H on Od. 11. 547.Eustathius (p. 1698) cannot, I think, be regarded as a witness of independent authority on this point, though that has sometimes been assumed. Commenting on Ï€Î±á¿–Î´ÎµÏ‚ Î´á½² Î¤Ïá½½Ï‰Î½ Î´á½·ÎºÎ±ÏƒÎ±Î½, he says:â€”á¼°ÏƒÏ„á½³Î¿Î½ Î´á½² á½…Ï„Î¹ (1) Î¿á¼± Î¼á½²Î½ á¼Ï€Î»Î¿ÏŠÎºá½½Ï„ÎµÏá½¹Î½ Ï†Î±ÏƒÎ¹ Î¤Ïá¿¶Î±Ï‚ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼ˆÎ¸Î·Î½á¾¶Î½ Î´Î¹Îºá½±ÏƒÎ±Î¹ á½ˆÎ´Ï…ÏƒÏƒÎµá¿– ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î‘á¼´Î±Î½Ï„Î¹ Ï€ÎµÏá½¶ Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼ˆÏ‡Î¹Î»Î»á½³Ï‰Ï‚ á½…Ï€Î»Ï‰Î½ á¼Ïá½·Î¶Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹, ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î´á½´ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Îšá½¹ÏŠÎ½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ [ Quint. Smyrn. 5. 128 ff.] Î´Î¹Î±ÏƒÎºÎµÏ…á½±Î¶ÎµÎ¹ á¼Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Î±á½‘Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï„á½´Î½ Î´á½·ÎºÎ·Î½ á¿¥Î·Ï„Î¿ÏÎ¹Îºá¿¶Ï‚. (2) á¼•Ï„ÎµÏÎ¿Î¹ Î´á½³ Ï†Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á½…Ï„Î¹ á¼Ï€á½·Ï„Î·Î´ÎµÏ‚ á¼ˆÎ³Î±Î¼á½³Î¼Î½Ï‰Î½ Ï†Ï…Î»Î±Ï„Ï„á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ Ï„á½¸ Î´á½¹Î¾Î±Î¹ Î¸Î±Ï„á½³Ïá¿³ Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼¡Ïá½½Ï‰Î½ Ï‡Î±Ïá½·ÏƒÎ±ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹, Î±á¼°Ï‡Î¼Î±Î»á½½Ï„Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î¤Ïá½½Ï‰Î½ ÏƒÏ…Î½Î±Î³Î±Î³á½½Î½, á¼¤ÏÎµÏ„Î¿ Îº.Ï„.Î». Here he is repeating, partly verbatim, Schol. H on Hom. Od. 11. 547, to which he adds nothing new. Thus he distinguishes two versions. (1) That in which the judges are simply â€˜the Trojans,â€™ with Athenaâ€”as in the Odyssey. He names Quintus Smyrnaeus in connection with this versionâ€”and for a reason which can, I think, be perceived; Quintus makes Nestor say, Ï„Î¿á½”Î½ÎµÎºÎ± Î¤ÏÏ‰Ïƒá½¶Î½ á¼Ï†á¿¶Î¼ÎµÎ½ á¼á¿£Ï†ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ¹ Ï„á½µÎ½Î´Îµ Î´Î¹Îºá½±ÏƒÏƒÎ±Î¹ Îº.Ï„.Î». (5. 157). Eustathius noticed or remembered this,â€”but not that, by Î¤ÏÏ‰Ïƒá½·Î½, the Nestor of Quintus meant the Trojan prisoners in the camp (as he presently explains, v. 160). (2) The version given by â€˜othersâ€™ (á¼•Ï„ÎµÏÎ¿Î¹ï¼‰â€”in which the Trojan prisoners judgedâ€” was manifestly known to Eustathius only from the scholium on the Odyssey, which he reproduces. there deserve attention:â€”â€˜The story is from the Cyclic poets. Agamemnon, on his guard against seeming to favour either of the competitors for the arms of Achilles, brought some Trojan prisoners, and asked them by which of the two heroes they had been more injured,â€™ etc. There is no reason to doubt that the scholiast knew of this account as given in some poem (or poems) of the Epic Cycle. There is no warrant for assuming that he invented this statement to explain the verse on which he was commenting. But the Aethiopis and the Little Iliad are, so far as we know, the only Cyclic poems to which his allusion could refer. And in the Little Iliad the award of the arms was decided, not by Trojan prisoners in the Greek camp, but (as will be seen presently) by Trojan opinion reported from Troy itself. Presumably, then, it was in the Aethiopis that the Trojan prisoners acted as judges. Since that poem dated from the earlier part of the eighth century (circ. 776 B.C.), the verse in the Nekyia of the Odyssey, Ï€Î±á¿–Î´ÎµÏ‚ Î´á½² Î¤Ïá½½Ï‰Î½ Î´á½·ÎºÎ±ÏƒÎ±Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î Î±Î»Î»á½°Ï‚ á¼ˆÎ¸á½µÎ½Î·, may have been founded upon it. The Nekyia is, in great part, older, probably, than 800 B.C., but unquestionably received some additions in the course of the eighth and seventh centuries. It is not necessary, however, to suppose that the Nekyia was here indebted to the Aethiopis. Both may have used some older source now unknown. When the Homeric poet associates â€˜Pallas Athenaâ€™ with the Trojan judges, he need not be understood as conceiving that she actually presided over the award,â€”as in the Eumenides she presides at the first session of the Areiopagus,â€”but merely that she influenced the minds of the arbiters.

ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î½á¿¦Î½ á¼Ï€á½¶ ÏƒÎºÎ·Î½Î±á¿–Ï‚ ÏƒÎµ Î½Î±Ï…Ï„Î¹ÎºÎ±á¿–Ï‚ á½Ïá¿¶ ğŸ—©
Line 3

The author of the Little Iliad seems The Little Iliad.to have worked in a spirit quite different from that of ArctÃ®nus. The Aethiopis was a grave epic, more in the temper of the Iliad; while the other poem had more affinity to the Odyssey, more of the lighter Ionian vein, and a larger element of romance. The contest for the arms was managed in a way which indicates the desire to avoid imitation of some earlier poet who had referred the award to the Trojan captives. By Nestor's advice, the Greeks send spies to the walls of Troy, in the hope that they may overhear some Trojan comments on the rival Greek heroes. The spies are fortunate. At that very moment two Trojan maidens are discussing Ajax and Odysseus. One of them deems Ajax the braver, since he carried the corpse of Achilles out of the fray. The other, inspired by Athena, reproves her;â€”â€˜even a woman can bear a burden, when it is laid on her,â€”but she cannot fightâ€™; â€”and added, doubtless, that it was Odysseus who had protected the retreat. The Greek chiefs, on hearing the report of their messengers, adjudged the arms to OdysseusSchol. on Ar. Eq. 1056.The first maiden said, Î‘á¼´Î±Ï‚ Î¼á½²Î½ Î³á½°Ï á¼„ÎµÎ¹ÏÎµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼”ÎºÏ†ÎµÏÎµ Î´Î·ÏŠÎ¿Ï„á¿†Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á¼¥ÏÏ‰ Î Î·Î»Îµá½·Î´Î·Î½, Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼¤Î¸ÎµÎ»Îµ Î´á¿–Î¿Ï‚ á½ˆÎ´Ï…ÏƒÏƒÎµá½»Ï‚Â· The second answered (á¼ˆÎ¸Î·Î½á¾¶Ï‚ Ï€ÏÎ¿Î½Î¿á½·á¾³): Ï€á¿¶Ï‚ á¼Ï€ÎµÏ†Ï‰Î½á½µÏƒÏ‰; Ï€á¿¶Ï‚ Î¿á½ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° Îºá½¹ÏƒÎ¼Î¿Î½ á¼”ÎµÎ¹Ï€ÎµÏ‚; ÎºÎ±á½· ÎºÎµ Î³Ï…Î½á½´ Ï†á½³ÏÎ¿Î¹ á¼„Ï‡Î¸Î¿Ï‚, á¼Ï€Îµá½· ÎºÎµÎ½ á¼€Î½á½´Ï á¼Ï€Î¹Î¸Îµá½·Î·Â· á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Î¿á½Îº á¼‚Î½ Î¼Î±Ï‡á½³ÏƒÎ±Î¹Ï„Î¿. The last line and a half are in the text of Aristophanes. The scholiast designates the author as á½ Ï„á½´Î½ Î¼Î¹ÎºÏá½°Î½ á¼¸Î»Î¹á½±Î´Î± Ï€ÎµÏ€Î¿Î¹Î·Îºá½½Ï‚.. Ajax, stricken with frenzy, made the onslaught on the flocks and herds of the Greeks: and afterwards slew himselfProclus, in his abstract of the Little Iliad (Photius cod. 239): á¼¡ Ï„á¿¶Î½ á½…Ï€Î»Ï‰Î½ ÎºÏá½·ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚ Î³á½·Î½ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹, ÎºÎ±á½¶ á½ˆÎ´Ï…ÏƒÏƒÎµá½ºÏ‚ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° Î²Î¿á½»Î»Î·ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼ˆÎ¸Î·Î½á¾¶Ï‚ Î»Î±Î¼Î²á½±Î½ÎµÎ¹, Î‘á¼´Î±Ï‚ Î´á½² á¼Î¼Î¼Î±Î½á½´Ï‚ Î³ÎµÎ½á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ Ï„á½µÎ½ Ï„Îµ Î»Îµá½·Î±Î½ á¼ˆÏ‡Î±Î¹á¿¶Î½ Î»Ï…Î¼Î±á½·Î½ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼‘Î±Ï…Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼€Î½Î±Î¹ÏÎµá¿–.. Agamemnon, probably by the counsel of the seer Calchas, decreed that the body of Ajax should not receive the customary form of funeralâ€” i.e., should not be burned, but should be placed in a coffin, and interredEustathius on Il. 2. 557(p. 285): á½ Ï„á½´Î½ Î¼Î¹ÎºÏá½°Î½ á¼¸Î»Î¹á½±Î´Î± Î³Ïá½±ÏˆÎ±Ï‚ á¼±ÏƒÏ„Î¿ÏÎµá¿– Î¼Î·Î´á½² ÎºÎ±Ï…Î¸á¿†Î½Î±Î¹ ÏƒÏ…Î½á½µÎ¸Ï‰Ï‚ Ï„á½¸Î½ Î‘á¼´Î±Î½Ï„Î±, Ï„ÎµÎ¸á¿†Î½Î±Î¹ Î´á½² Î¿á½•Ï„Ï‰Ï‚ á¼Î½ ÏƒÎ¿Ïá¿·, Î´Î¹á½° Ï„á½´Î½ á½€ÏÎ³á½´Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î²Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î»á½³Ï‰Ï‚. The intervention of Calchas is mentioned by Philostratus Heroic. 11. 3.. Here, then, we have two traits which are distinctive of the story as handled by Sophocles, the onslaught of the mad Ajax on the cattle, and the idea that, after his death, his body was liable to be treated with some degree of penal dishonour. Both these traits, so far as can now be judged, were peculiar to the Little Iliad. In the other versionâ€”that indicated in the Odyssey and by Pindar, and probably given by ArctÃ®nusâ€”Ajax died guiltless of offence against the Greeks, and received, like Achilles, the spontaneous and uncontested tribute of public mourning.

Î‘á¼´Î±Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚, á¼”Î½Î¸Î± Ï„á½±Î¾Î¹Î½ á¼ÏƒÏ‡á½±Ï„Î·Î½ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹, ğŸ—©
Line 4

Before the age of the Attic dramatists, the Ajax Ajax and the Aeacidae. legend received some further developments which were probably unknown to the Cyclic poets. One of these was the enrolment of Ajax among the Aeacidae. The Iliad bestows the name of Î‘á¼°Î±Îºá½·Î´Î·Ï‚ on two persons only,â€”Peleus, the son, and Achilles, the grandson, of Aeacus. The logographer Pherecydes Apollod. 3. 12.Â§ 6. (circ. 480 B.C.) made Telamon the son of Actaeus and GlaucÃ¨, a daughter of the Aeginetan hero Cychreus,â€”recognising no tie, except friendship, between Telamon and Peleus. According to another legend, however, both Peleus and Telamon were sons of Aeacus by EndeÃ¯s Apollod. l.c. This á¼˜Î½Î´Î·á¿“Ï‚ appears in Megarian legend as a daughter of Î£ÎºÎµá½·ÏÏ‰Î½ or Î£Îºá½·ÏÏ‰Î½ of Megara ( Paus. 2. 29. 9; Plut. Thes. 10). Another legend makes her a daughter of Cheiron (schol. Pind. N. 5. 12: schol. Il. 16. 14: Hyginus Fab. 14). In Apollod. l.c. the MSS. have á¼˜Î½Î´Î·á¿“Î´Î± Ï„á½´Î½ Î£ÎºÎµá½·ÏÏ‰Î½Î¿Ï‚: but Aegius in his edition (Rome, 1555) gave Î§Îµá½·ÏÏ‰Î½Î¿Ï‚, which Heyne (ed. 1803) retained. (á¼˜Î½Î´Î·á¿“Ï‚=á¼”Î³Î³Î±Î¹Î¿Ï‚ or á¼”Î³Î³ÎµÎ¹Î¿Ï‚, from the Doric Î´á¾¶=Î³á¿†). The cult of Aeacus, son of Zeus, had its chief seat in the island called after his mother, the nymph Aegina. Telamon and Ajax belonged to Salamis. By making Telamon and Peleus brothers, the Aeginetans linked their local hero with the others. This engrafting of Telamon and his son on the Aeacid stock had gained general acceptance before the fifth century B.C. The sculptures of Athena's temple at Aegina date from the period of the Persian wars. On the east pediment Heracles and Telamon were the prominent figures; on the west, Ajax was seen defending the corpse of Achilles. Herodotus8. 64 á¼”Î´Î¿Î¾Îµ Î´á½³ ÏƒÏ†Î¹ Îµá½”Î¾Î±ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹ Î¸ÎµÎ¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼Ï€Î¹ÎºÎ±Î»á½³ÏƒÎ±ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ Î‘á¼°Î±Îºá½·Î´Î±Ï‚ ÏƒÏ…Î¼Î¼á½±Ï‡Î¿Ï…Ï‚, á½¡Ï‚ Î´á½³ ÏƒÏ†Î¹ á¼”Î´Î¿Î¾Îµ,...Î±á½Ï„á½¹Î¸ÎµÎ½ Î¼á½²Î½ á¼Îº Î£Î±Î»Î±Î¼á¿–Î½Î¿Ï‚ Î‘á¼´Î±Î½Ï„á½± Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¤ÎµÎ»Î±Î¼á¿¶Î½Î± á¼Ï€ÎµÎºÎ±Î»á½³Î¿Î½Ï„Î¿, á¼Ï€á½¶ Î´á½² Î‘á¼°Î±Îºá½¸Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ á¼„Î»Î»Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Î‘á¼°Î±Îºá½·Î´Î±Ï‚ Î½á½³Î± á¼€Ï€á½³ÏƒÏ„ÎµÎ»Î»Î¿Î½ á¼Ï‚ Î‘á¼´Î³Î¹Î½Î±Î½. It has generally been supposed that the ship sent to Aegina was intended to bring sacred images or symbols of the Aeacidae (so CurtiusE. , Hist. Gr. II. p. 291 Eng. tr.). Stein, however, thinks that the object was merely to make the invocation at Aegina in the proper form; and would similarly explain the presence of the Dioscuri with the Spartan armies ( Her. 5. 75) in a purely spiritual sense.â€”After the victory, three Phoenician triremes were dedicated by the Greeks to deities who had helped themâ€” one to Poseidon at the Isthmus, one to Athena at Sunium, and one to Ajax at Salamis ( Her. 8. 121). says that when the Greeks had resolved, just before the battle of Salamis, â€˜to invoke the Aeacidae as allies,â€™ they called on Ajax and Telamon to come to them from Salamis itself, but sent a ship to Aegina to summon â€˜Aeacus and the other Aeacidaeâ€™ (i.e., Peleus, and his son Achilles; Phocus, and his sons Crisus and Panopeus). The passage has an especial interest as showing that, though Ajax had now been thoroughly adopted into the Aeacid cult of Aegina, this had been done without weakening the immemorial tradition which made Salamis his home.

Another addition Ajax invulnerable.to the Ajax legendâ€”worthy of notice, since Aeschylus used itâ€”is that which made the hero invulnerable. This was borrowed from the story of Achilles,â€” which, indeed, influenced at several points the later development of the Ajax-myth: and it served also to connect Ajax with Heracles. In Pindar's fifth Isthmian ode, Heracles, the guest of Telamon at Salamis, prays that his host may have a son, as â€˜staunch of frameâ€™ as the hide of the Nemean lion which he himself is wearing Isthm. 5. 47á¼„ÏÏÎ·ÎºÏ„Î¿Î½ Ï†Ï…á½±Î½, á½¥ÏƒÏ€ÎµÏ Ï„á½¹Î´Îµ Î´á½³ÏÎ¼Î± Î¼Îµ Î½á¿¦Î½ Ï€ÎµÏÎ¹Ï€Î»Î±Î½á¾¶Ï„Î±Î¹ | Î¸Î·Ïá½¹Ï‚.. From some such germ grew the story that Ajax had been born before the arrival of Heracles, who wrapped the child in the lion-skin, making him invulnerable, except in one place which the hide had not coveredTzetzes on Lycophron 455â€”461. Argument to Soph. Ai.ï¼ˆad fin.), and schol. on v. 833.. This legend is unknown to the IliadThus in Il. 23. 822 the Greeks fear that Ajax may be wounded by Diomedes.; but in Plato's time it was generally currentPlat. Symp. 219 E (Ï‡Ïá½µÎ¼<*>) Ï€Î¿Î»á½º Î¼á¾¶Î»Î»Î¿Î½ á¼„Ï„ÏÏ‰Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á¼¦Î½ Ï€Î±Î½Ï„Î±Ï‡á¿‡ (sc. á½ Î£Ï‰ÎºÏá½±Ï„Î·Ï‚) á¼¢ ÏƒÎ¹Î´á½µÏá¿³ á½ Î‘á¼´Î±Ï‚..

5 Ï€á½±Î»Î±Î¹ ÎºÏ…Î½Î·Î³ÎµÏ„Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼ÎµÏ„ÏÎ¿á½»Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 5

Aeschylus handled the story of Ajax in a trilogy. The The trilogy of Aeschylus. (i) á½Ï€Î»Ï‰Î½ ÎºÏá½·ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚. first play was called á½Ï€Î»Ï‰Î½ ÎºÏá½·ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚, the Award of the Arms. Aristotle includes this title (without naming Aeschylus) in a list of ten tragedies of which the subjects were taken from the Little Iliad Poet.c. 23 ad fin.. It would be unsafe to found too much upon this notice. Aristotle may have meant, not a particular tragedy entitled á½Ï€Î»Ï‰Î½ ÎºÏá½·ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚, but, more generally, that episode, as a tragic subject; thus the contest for the arms was certainly included in the Ajax of Theodectes, to which Aristotle more than once alludes in the Rhetoric (see below, Â§ 19). We cannot assume, then, that the version given in the Little Iliad was that which Aeschylus followed. WelckerUeber den Aias des Sophokles, in Rhein. Mus. for 1829, part 3, p. 53. thinks that Aeschylus, following the Aethiopis of ArctÃ®nus, made the Trojan captives the judges, and omitted the onslaught of Ajax on the cattle. As to the judges, it is obvious that tragedy could not use the almost playful romance of the Little Iliad, and represent the question as decided by the conversation between the Trojan maidens. One of Welcker's chief reasons for thinking that the captives formed the tribunal is that the á½Ï€Î»Ï‰Î½ ÎºÏá½·ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚ had a second title, namely, Î¦Ïá½»Î³ÎµÏ‚,â€”these â€˜Phrygiansâ€™ being the Trojan captives who acted as judges: but this hypothesis as to the second title has no good foundationNo such second title appears in any one of the five ancient citations of the ÎŸÏ€Î»Ï‰Î½ ÎºÏá½·ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚ (Nauck, Trag. Frag., pp. 57 f.).. On this point, then, we must be content to remark that the Trojans appear as the judges not only in the Odyssey, but also in the Heroica of Philostratus, in Quintus Smyrnaeus, and in the Posthomerica of Tzetzes Heroic. 11. 3: Quint. Smyrn. 5. 157: Tzetzes Posthom. 485.. Now, after the age of Attic tragedy, the Aethiopis of ArctÃ®nus, like other Cyclic epics, fell into comparative obscurity, so much of the material having been worked up in the more attractive form of drama. The earliest writer, of known dateThe scholia which name or indicate ArctÃ®nus, such as those on Il. 11. 515 and Pind. Isthm. 4.(3.) 58, may, of course, be older, or represent older sources., who names ArctÃ®nus, is Dionysius of Halicarnassus (circ. 25 B.C.)Ant. Rom. 1. 68.. It would seem that neither Strabo nor Pausanias knew the AethiopisAs to Strabo, see Mr Monro in Journ. Hellen. Stud. IV. p. 16, n. 1; as to Pausanias, ib. p. 31, n. 1.. When, therefore, Philostratus (circ. 235 A.D. ), or Quintus Smyrnaeus (circ. 450 A.D. ), represents the Trojan captives as the judges, it is much less probable that he derived that version from ArctÃ®nus than that he found it in some old writer of wider popularity, such as Aeschylus. It is, of course, a bare possibility that these late writers relied solely on the verse in the Odyssey; but it is very unlikely. I think, therefore, that Welcker's view on this point has much in its favour, although the ground on which he chiefly rests it (the supposed second title of the play) is untenable. With regard to the general treatment of the subject by Aeschylus, one important fact is certain. Ajax and Odysseus argued their respective claims in speechesThis is proved by a fragment of the á½Ï€Î»Ï‰Î½ ÎºÏá½·ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚ ( Aesch. frag. 175, ed. Nauck), manifestly from a speech of Ajax, who taunts Odysseus with being the son of Sisyphus: á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼ˆÎ½Ï„Î¹ÎºÎ»Îµá½·Î±Ï‚ á¼†ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Î½ á¼¦Î»Î¸Îµ Î£á½·ÏƒÏ…Ï†Î¿Ï‚, Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Ïƒá¿†Ï‚ Î»á½³Î³Ï‰ Ï„Î¿Î¹ Î¼Î·Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼¥ Ïƒâ€™ á¼Î³Îµá½·Î½Î±Ï„Î¿.â€”as they do in Ovid and Quintus Smyrnaeus, and as we know that they did in Theodectes. It may perhaps jar somewhat on our conception of Aeschylusâ€”whose style, as we know it, is so remote from rhetoric of the kind which afterwards became popular at Athens â€”to imagine him pitting his two heroes against each other in controversial speeches; but there is the trial-scene in the Eumenides to remind us how he could treat a subject of the forensic type without loss of tragic and heroic elevation. The pleading of his Ajax and his Odysseus had probably more resemblance to a controversy in the Iliad than to such an encounter of wits as Euripides would have provided on a similar occasion.

The second play of the trilogy was the Î˜Ïá¿‡ÏƒÏƒÎ±Î¹. These (ii) Î˜Ïá¿‡ÏƒÏƒÎ±Î¹. Thracian women, who formed the Chorus, were captives of Ajax. Tecmessa, in Quintus Smyrnaeus, says that her lord had carried her away from her home, â€˜along with other women, prizes of war Quint. Smyrn. 5. 541á¼…Î¼â€™ á¼„Î»Î»á¿ƒÏ‚ Î»Î·ÏŠá½±Î´ÎµÏƒÏƒÎ¹..â€™ The function of this Chorus was similar to that of the Salaminian sailors in Sophocles, to express reverence for Ajax, to mourn with him in his unjust defeat, and especially to sympathise with Tecmessa, a captive like themselves, and one whose lot was to be reduced, by the hero's death, to a level with their ownThe ancient scholiast on Soph. Ai. 134, after commending Sophocles for forming his Chorus of Salaminians, observes:â€”Ï„á½¸ Î´á½² Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î±á¼°Ï‡Î¼Î±Î»á½½Ï„Ï‰Î½ ÎºÎ·Î´ÎµÎ¼Î¿Î½Î¹Îºá½¸Î½ Î¼á½³Î½, á½¡Ï‚ Î‘á¼°ÏƒÏ‡á½»Î»Î¿Ï‚ á¼Î½ Î˜Ïá¿„ÏƒÏƒÎ±Î¹Ï‚, Î¿á½ Î¼á½´Î½ Îµá½Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÏ‰Ï€Î¿Î½Â· á½…ÏÎ± Î³á½°Ï Î¿á¼·Î¿Î½ Î±á¼°Ï‡Î¼Î±Î»á½½Ï„Î¿Ï…Ï‚ á¼Ï€Î¹Ï„Î¹Î¼á¾¶Î½ Ï„á¿· ÎœÎµÎ½ÎµÎ»á½±á¿³. He means that the condition of the captives is well suited to the expression of sympathy (ÎºÎ·Î´ÎµÎ¼Î¿Î½Î¹Îºá½¹Î½), but not, on the whole, suited to their part (Îµá½Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÏ‰Ï€Î¿Î½): for it is unseemly that captives should censure MenelaÃ¼s. Hence we learn that the Chorus in the Î˜Ïá¿‡ÏƒÏƒÎ±Î¹ denounced the part taken by the Atreidae in the award of the arms.. The suicide of Ajax was related by a messengerSchol. on Soph. Ai. 815Ï†Î¸á½±Î½ÎµÎ¹ Î‘á¼°ÏƒÏ‡á½»Î»Î¿Ï‚ á¼Î½ Î˜Ïá¿„ÏƒÏƒÎ±Î¹Ï‚ Ï„á½´Î½ á¼€Î½Î±á½·ÏÎµÏƒÎ¹Î½ Î‘á¼´Î±Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Î´á¼° á¼€Î³Î³á½³Î»Î¿Ï… á¼€Ï€Î±Î³Î³Îµá½·Î»Î±Ï‚.. Aeschylus adopted the legend already mentionedâ€”that Ajax was invulnerable, except at one place (in the side, according to one account), which the lion-hide of Heracles had not covered. The messenger told how, when Ajax first attempted to slay himself, the sword bent against his body, â€˜as when a man bends a bow.â€™ But anon a divine being came to him: she it was who showed him the place at which he must drive in the swordSchol. on Soph. Ai. 833Ï†Î·Ïƒá½¶ Î´á½² Ï€ÎµÏá½¶ Î±á½Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î‘á¼°ÏƒÏ‡á½»Î»Î¿Ï‚ á½…Ï„Î¹ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á½¸ Î¾á½·Ï†Î¿Ï‚ á¼Îºá½±Î¼Ï€Ï„ÎµÏ„Î¿ Î¿á½Î´Î±Î¼á¿‡ á¼Î½Î´Î¹Î´á½¹Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï‡ÏÏ‰Ï„á½¸Ï‚ Ï„á¿‡ ÏƒÏ†Î±Î³á¿‡ Ï„á½¹Î¾Î¿Î½ á½¥Ï‚ Ï„Î¹Ï‚ á¼Î½Ï„Îµá½·Î½Ï‰Î½ Ï€Ïá½¶Î½ Î´á½µ Ï„Î¹Ï‚, Ï†Î·Ïƒá½·, Ï€Î±ÏÎ¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ± Î´Î±á½·Î¼Ï‰Î½ á¼”Î´ÎµÎ¹Î¾ÎµÎ½ Î±á½Ï„á¿· ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° Ï€Î¿á¿–Î¿Î½ Î¼á½³ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Î´Îµá¿– Ï‡Ïá½µÏƒÎ±ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Ï„á¿‡ ÏƒÏ†Î±Î³á¿‡.. The simple fact that the suicide of Ajax was narrated by an eye-witness, who could describe the circumstances attending it, at once indicates how profoundly Aeschylus must have differed from Sophocles in his treatment of this subject. In the psychology of Ajax, as delineated by Sophocles, we can trace the growth of those complex feelings which imperiously required that his deed should be done in complete security from the witness of human eye or ear, so that he might be alone with his deliberate thoughts, and with the gods to whom he speaks them.

Îµá¼´Ï„â€™ á¼”Î½Î´Î¿Î½ Îµá¼´Ï„â€™ Î¿á½Îº á¼”Î½Î´Î¿Î½. Îµá½– Î´á½³ Ïƒâ€™ á¼ÎºÏ†á½³ÏÎµÎ¹ ğŸ—©
Line 7

The place (iii) Î£Î±Î»Î±Î¼á½·Î½Î¹Î±Î¹.of the Î£Î±Î»Î±Î¼á½·Î½Î¹Î±Î¹ as the third play of this trilogy, and the nature of the subject, may be considered certainThey were first recognised by Welcker: see Rhein. Mus. (1829) pp. 56 ff. It is known from Ar. Ran. 1041 that â€˜lion-hearted Teucerâ€™ figured prominently in some work of Aeschylus,â€”an allusion which can hardly refer to any subordinate part that he may have borne in the á½Ï€Î»Ï‰Î½ ÎºÏá½·ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚ or the Î˜Ïá¿‡ÏƒÏƒÎ±Î¹. And, except the Î£Î±Î»Î±Î¼á½·Î½Î¹Î±Î¹, no lost play of Aeschylus is known by name in which Teucer could have been a principal person.. After the death of Ajax, Teucer returns to Salamis, bringing with him the child Eurysaces (confided to his care by Ajax); he is met with reproaches by his father, the aged and lonely Telamon, who blames him for the death of Ajax; and goes forth to found the new Salamis in Cyprus. With regard to the â€˜Salaminian womenâ€™â€”the Chorus who gave the title to the playâ€”it is well to remember that, when the protagonist of a Greek play is a man (as Teucer here), but the Chorus female, this regularly denotes that a woman has some important, though secondary, part in the action; as CreÃ¼sa, for example, in the Ion, where the Chorus is formed by her handmaids. The â€˜Salaminian womenâ€™ stood (we may conjecture) in a like relation to Eriboea, the mother of Ajax. In the play of Sophocles the Salaminian sailors imagine the passionate grief with which she will hear the evil tidings of her son; and Ajax vividly expresses the same foreboding. Itis very possible (I think) that these passages were suggested by the prominent place which the laments of Eriboea and her handmaids held in the SalaminiaeBoth these passages in the Ajax have a noteworthy emphasis. (1) In the first, vv. 622â€”634, the Salaminian sailors dwell on Eriboea's grief, which they are merely predicting, at a length, and with a degree of detail, which arrest attention. (2) In vv. 850 f., Ajax, after briefly mentioning both his parents, goes on to speak of the manner in which his mother's sorrow will be manifested. The Î‘á¼°á½±Î½Ï„ÎµÎ¹Î± of Aeschylus was probably one of his earlier trilogiesâ€”written, perhaps, while the new lustre shed on Ajax by the victory at Salamis was still fresh. In that case, the lyric element in the Î£Î±Î»Î±Î¼á½·Î½Î¹Î±Î¹ may have been very large, giving ample scope for ÎºÎ¿Î¼Î¼Î¿á½· between Eriboea and the Chorus.. â€˜The island of Ajax,â€™ as Aeschylus calls Salamis, had a cult of the hero, including an annual festival (Î‘á¼°á½±Î½Ï„ÎµÎ¹Î±); and an impressive conclusion would be given to the trilogy by Telamon decreeing honours to the memory of his son.

ÎºÏ…Î½á½¸Ï‚ Î›Î±ÎºÎ±á½·Î½Î·Ï‚ á½¥Ï‚ Ï„Î¹Ï‚ Îµá½”ÏÎ¹Î½Î¿Ï‚ Î²á½±ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚. ğŸ—©
Line 8

The award of the arms was not dramatised by Sophocles. The Ajax of Sophocles. In his Ajax he assumes, like Pindar, that the award was decided by the Greek chiefs. For the rest, the outline of his plot is taken from the Little Iliad.

The scene is laid before the tent of Ajax, at the eastern end Analysis of the play. I. Prologue: 1â€”133. of the Greek camp, on the northern coast of the Troad. The time is early morning. Odysseus is scanning foot-prints on the ground,â€”walking to and fro as he does so, in perplexity. The goddess Athena (who is invisible, probably, to him, though seen by the spectators) speaks to him, and tells him that she can resolve his doubts. Ajax, whom he seeks, is within yonder tent. And Ajax has really done the outrage of which he is suspected: it is he who, in the past night, butchered the oxen and sheep of the Greeks, along with the men in charge of them. His plan had been to murder the Greek chiefs, beginning with the Atreidae; but, just as he had reached their tents, Athena struck him with frenzy, and turned his rage aside upon the cattle. At this moment he is tormenting some of the animals in his tent, fancying that they are the Greek princes. And she will show him to Odysseus. She then calls Ajax to come forth. Odysseus is alarmed at the prospect of being confronted with this raging madman: but the goddess reassures him; the maniac shall not see him.

Then Ajax comes out, with a blood-stained scourge in his hand, and boasts, with wild laughter, of his triumphs. He has killed the Atreidae, and now he is going to flog Odysseus to death. When he returns to his task, Athena reads the moral to her favourite. Let him beware of sinning, through pride, against the gods, as Ajax has done. â€˜A day can humble all human things, and a day can lift them up; but the wise of heart are loved of the gods, and the evil are abhorred.â€™ Athena then disappears; and Odysseus departs.

The Chorus of Salaminians, followers of Ajax,â€”at once Parodos: 134â€”200. sailors and warriors,â€”now enter. They have heard the rumour that Ajax is the author of the onslaught on the cattle, and are keenly disquieted. If the deed has really been his, he must have been driven to it by some angry deity who demented him. But they rather believe that it is a slander, prompted by the jealousy of the Greek chiefs. He has been too long secluded; let him arise, and clear his good name, which is theirs also.

At this moment II. First episode: 201â€”595. (First Kommos: 201â€”262.) Tecmessa comes to them from the tent. She tells them that Ajax has gone mad, and has been slaughtering cattle in the tent. Thus they learn that the worst is true. In the lyric dialogue (kommos) which follows, they learn further that the frenzy of Ajax is past; he is sane again, but is plunged in the deepest despondency. She has just finished a detailed account of what happened in the nightâ€”how her lord sallied forth, how he returned, and how, while tormenting his victims, he conversed with â€˜some phantomâ€™ at the tent-doorâ€”when Ajax himself is heard calling from within. She opens the door of the tent (i.e., the interior is disclosed by the eccyclema), and Ajax is seen sitting amidst the slaughtered cattle.

He cries (Second Kommos: 348â€”429.) to his trusty friends to slay him; he is disgraced, and has become a mockery to his foes: this shame has blotted out his past deeds. In vain the Chorus and Tecmessa try to comfort him. Each successive utterance makes it clearer that he can think of only one refuge. When at last he has said this plainlyâ€”reviewing the whole situation in which he finds himself, and reasoning out the conclusion that nothing remains for him but to dieâ€”Tecmessa makes her appeal. Let him think what his death will mean for her and for his child. His only reply is to command that the boy shall be brought to him. This is done; and the touching words which he then speaks (incidentally showing his affection for Tecmessa) are words of farewell. He charges the Chorus with his last injunctions for Teucer, who is to see that his armour is buried with him,â€”saving only the shield which his son Eurysaces (who takes his name from it) is to keep. And Teucer shall take Eurysaces home to Telamon and Eriboea in Salamis.â€”He then sternly commands Tecmessa to retire, with the child. She addresses him with despairing entreaties; but he roughly silences her, and withdraws into the tent.

The Chorus, First stasimon: 596â€”645. whose thoughts turn wistfully to Salamis, lament how their hard lot at Troy is now aggravated by this new and dread affliction of their lord. They deplore his cruel fate, and imagine the grief of his aged parents. His plight is indeed such that death might well seem a lesser evil.

Ajax re-enters, with a sword in his hand. He had lately III. Second episode: 646â€”692. parted from his friends with an open and stern expression of his resolve to die. But now his first words announce at least a change of mood. Time can alter all things; and he has been softened. He is going â€˜to purge his stains,â€™ and â€˜to buryâ€™ his sword. He wishes â€˜to avoidâ€™ the anger of Athena; and â€˜henceforthâ€™ he will know how to yield to the godsâ€”and to revere the Atreidae. Perhaps they will soon hear that all is well with him.

A discussion of this speech will be found below (Â§ 12). Its Hyporcheme (serving as second stasimon): 693â€”718. effect is to throw the Chorus into a transport of joy, to which they give vent in song, accompanied by lively dance. So Ajax has been reconciled to the gods, and has forgiven the Atreidae! The trouble is overpast!

A Messenger enters from the Greek camp. Teucer has just IV. Third episode: 719â€”865. returned from a foray in the Mysian uplands. On his arrival, the infuriated Greeks had thronged around him, denouncing him as â€˜the kinsman of the maniac,â€™ and threatening to stone him. Meanwhile the Greek chiefs had met in council before Agamemnon's tent. The seer Calchas, drawing apart from their circle, had given a private and friendly warning to Teucer. Ajax, he said, had incurred the anger of Athena, by proud words formerly spoken. But her anger will pursue him for this day only. If, during this day, he can be kept within the tent, his life may be saved.

On learning that Ajax has just gone out, the Messenger is filled with dismay, which the Chorus share. They call forth Tecmessa. On hearing what Calchas has said, she implores the Chorus at once to aid her in seeking Ajax. The Chorus now leave the orchestra, in two divisions. One division goes out on the left of the spectators, to search the coast eastward from the camp: the other goes out on the right, to search westwards. Tecmessa also goes forth, and the Messenger departs.

A change of scene now takes placeâ€”from the ground in front of the tent, to a lonely spot on the sea-shore, fringed with underwood. (The change of scene in the Eumenides, from Delphi to Athens, is the only other certain instance in Greek Tragedy.)

Ajax is seen standing near the sword which he has fixed by its hilt in the ground. He invokes Zeusâ€”to save his corpse from dishonour, by apprising Teucer: Hermesâ€”to give him swift convoy to the nether world: the Furiesâ€”to avenge him on the Greeks: Heliosâ€”to tell the news in his island-home: Thanatosâ€”to release him. Then he bids farewell to Salamis, to Athens, to the springs, rivers, and plains of Troy: and falls upon his sword.

The Chorus Epiparodos: 866â€”878. Third Kommos: 879â€”973. re-enter the orchestra in two bands (as they left it), from opposite sides. They do not see the body of Ajax, which is screened by the underwood amid which it fell. While deploring the failure of their search, they hear a sharp cry of anguish from the copse near them. It is Tecmessa, who has found what they sought. She will not suffer them to see what she has seen, but covers the body with a robe.

Amid the laments V. Fourth episode: 974â€” 1184. which follow, Teucer hastens in: Zeus had heard the prayer of Ajax; â€˜a swift rumour, as from a god,â€™ had come to the brother. His first thought is for the child that Ajax had bequeathed to his care; and on learning that Eurysaces has been left at the tent, he sends Tecmessa to fetch him. He then unshrouds the corpse; his bitter grief has free course; and as he withdraws the sword from the body which it has transfixed, he remembers that it was Hector's fatal gift.

MenelaÃ¼s now enters, and roughly tells Teucer that the body of Ajax is to remain where it lies, unburied. Ajax was a worse than Trojan foe; he had plotted the murder of his comrades, who were saved only by divine interposition. Reverence for authority shall be upheld: Ajax defied the Atreidae while he lived, but they will dispose of him in death. Teucer replies to the second part of the indictmentâ€”the charge of insubordination. Ajax was an independent ally, not a vassal of the Atreidae. In the stormy altercation which follows, MenelaÃ¼s has the worst of it, and departs, with a hint that he can bring force to bear.

He has just gone, when Tecmessa comes, with the child Eurysaces, for whom Teucer had sent her to the tent. (Henceforth she is a mute person.) The child is now made to kneel, in the posture of a suppliant, by his father's body, holding in his hand locks of hair (his own, Tecmessa's, and Teucer's), as offerings to the dead. Teucer fears that MenelaÃ¼s may seek to separate the kinsfolk from the body of Ajax by force: he therefore places the body under this religious safeguard of a formal â€˜supplication,â€™ and invokes a solemn curse on any one who may attempt to remove the suppliant by violence. He then goes out, to choose a place for the grave of Ajax.

The Chorus bewail their hardships at Troy. Ajax was once Third stasimon: 1185â€” 1222. their comfort, and they have lost him. Would that they could pass Sunium, and greet sacred Athens!

Teucer re-enters hurriedly, having noticed the approach of VI. Exodos: 1223â€” 1420. Agamemnon, who appears directly afterwards. Agamemnon reproves the presumption of Teucer (â€˜the captive woman's sonâ€™). What, after all, was this Ajax? â€˜Whither went he, or where stood he, where I was not?â€™ Ajax lost the arms: that is no reason why Teucer should attack the judges. â€˜Sober thyself, I say;â€”recall thy birth;â€”bring hither someone else,â€”a freeborn man,â€”who shall plead thy cause for thee before us.â€™ Teucer makes a scathing reply. He reminds the king who it was that saved the ships from Trojan fire and sword,â€”who it was that met Hector in single combat. â€˜Were these deeds not his, who, thou sayest, nowhere set foot where thou wast not?â€™ As to the taunt that he, Teucer, is disqualified by birth for being the champion of Ajaxâ€”can the son of Atreus and AÃ«ropÃ¨ say that to the son of Telamon and HesionÃ¨? With Tecmessa and Eurysaces, he is ready to die in this cause.

At this pointâ€”when nothing seems to remain but that the Atreidae should enforce their willâ€”Odysseus enters. He intercedes with Agamemnon, who is ready to hear â€˜his best friend.â€™ â€˜Ajax,â€™ he says, â€˜was my bitterest foe, after I won the armsâ€™: but â€˜in all our Greek host which came to Troy, I have seen none who was his peer, save Achilles.â€™ Agamemnon argues, wavers, and finally says that, though he will always detest Ajax, Odysseus may do as he pleases.

The king having gone, Odysseus proffers friendship to Teucer, and expresses a wish to take part in the obsequies. Teucer warmly thanks him,â€”contrasting his noble conduct with that of the Atreidae. He fears to accept the co-operation of Odysseus in the actual rites, lest that should displease the dead; but will welcome his presence as a spectator, and his help in conciliating the army. Odysseus assents, and withdraws.

Various tasks in relation to the funeral are now assigned to the Chorus by Teucer. He raises the body of the hero, directing the child to lay his hand upon it, that he too may have a part in the office. Then Ajax is carried forth, followed by his wife and his son, with Teucer and the Salaminian warriors, to be laid by the Hellespont in his grave at Cape Rhoeteum, the grave which was to be â€˜ever memorable among menThe words of the Chorus in vv. 1166 f., Î²ÏÎ¿Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼€Îµá½·Î¼Î½Î·ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½ | Ï„á½±Ï†Î¿Î½..â€™

á¼”Î½Î´Î¿Î½ Î³á½°Ï á¼Î½á½´Ï á¼„ÏÏ„Î¹ Ï„Ï…Î³Ï‡á½±Î½ÎµÎ¹, Îºá½±ÏÎ± ğŸ—©
Line 9

The first question Dramatic unity of the play. which this play suggests is one which must be considered before any criticism of detail can be profitably attemptedâ€”before, indeed, even the character of the hero himself, as drawn by Sophocles, can be properly appreciated. How did the poet conceive the subject of his drama as a whole? What was the nature of the unity which he intended his work to possess? Ajax dies at verse 865: more than a third of the play follows his death, and is concerned with the question as to whether he is, or is not, to be buried. A reader is apt to feel that, with the suicide of Ajax, the principal interest has disappeared. Modern criticism has suggested various apologies for the latter part of the play; the supreme importance which the ancient Greeks attached to funeral rites, as affecting the condition of the departed spirit; the advantage incidental to the controversy between Teucer and the Atreidae, that the merits of Ajax are triumphantly asserted; the edifying victory of prudence and magnanimity in the person of Odysseus. All such considerations, however, tend only to show, first, that this part of the play would have been interesting, on general grounds, to a Greek audience; and secondly, that it is not irrelevant to the subject of the earlier portion. But more than this is required, if the sequel to the hero's death is to be justified as a matter of dramatic art. It has to be explained how the action of the play, from beginning to end, can be regarded as an organic whole. The idea which pervades it, giving it unity and coherence, must be such that the death of Ajax can be viewed, not as a catastrophe after which everything else becomes tame, but rather as a tragic event necessarily leading to the events which follow it, so that the true climax is reached only in that decision which rescues the corpse of Ajax from dishonour. We must endeavour to trace this idea; or, in other words, to find the point of view from which Sophocles may be supposed to have regarded his own work.

10 ÏƒÏ„á½±Î¶Ï‰Î½ á¼±Î´Ïá¿¶Ï„Î¹ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï‡á½³ÏÎ±Ï‚ Î¾Î¹Ï†Î¿ÎºÏ„á½¹Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚. ğŸ—©
Line 10

The first circumstance which demands notice is the fact The veto on the burial. that Athena visited Ajax with madness only at the moment when he already stood, in the darkness of night, before the tents of the Atreidae, prepared to murder them in their sleep. He was still sane when he plotted that bloody vengeance against them and the other chiefs. When, after his madness, he regains his sanity, he bitterly laments, at first, that his plan had been foiled. The award of the arms had been unjust. But, none the less, Ajax had merited, by his murderous design, the resentment of the Atreidae and of the Greek army. The public feeling in the camp, on the morning after the outrage, would have fully sustained Agamemnon in visiting him with the extreme penalty which the usage of that age sanctioned in regard to public enemiesâ€”the refusal of sepulture. The poet has taken care to let us know thisâ€”before the death of Ajaxâ€”by the mouth of the messenger who brings the warning of Calchas to Teucer. The Greeks, crowding around Teucer, threaten to stone him, guiltless as he is, merely because he is â€˜the kinsman of the maniac who had plotted against the armyVv. 726 ff..â€™ Ajax himself, in his last speech, forebodes that burial will be refused to him; his only prayer to Zeus is that his body may not be cast to the dogs and birds. The spectators are thus clearly forewarned that, after the fall of Ajax, anger must inevitably break forth against him, menacing him with a calamity more dreadful than death. Hence the intervention of the Atreidae, when it occurs, appears as a necessary consequence of what has preceded. It is the bursting of a storm of which we have seen menacing signs, and even heard the first distant mutterings.
