á¼¦ Ï€Î¿á½» Ï„Î¹Î½Î¿Ï‚ Î½á½·ÎºÎ±Ï‚ á¼€Îºá½±ÏÏ€Ï‰Ï„Î¿Î½ Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î½, ğŸ—©
Line 176

á¼¦ Ï€Î¿Ï…, â€˜I weenâ€™: a phrase frequent in this play; cp. 382, 622, 850, 1008: Tr. 846.

Î½á½·ÎºÎ±Ï‚ Ï„Î¹Î½á½¸Ï‚ á¼€Îºá½±ÏÏ€Ï‰Ï„Î¿Î½ Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î½, on account of some victory (given by her to Ajax) which brought her no ÎºÎ±ÏÏ€á½¹Ï‚, no reward; á¼¤ á¿¥Î± â€¦ ÏˆÎµÏ…ÏƒÎ¸Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ± á¼Î½á½±ÏÏ‰Î½, either, it may be, because she was disappointed of spoils; Îµá¼´Ï„â€™ á¼€Î´á½½ÏÎ¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼Î»Î±Ï†Î±Î²Î¿Î»á½·Î±Î¹Ï‚, or by reason of deer-slaying after which he made no Î´á¿¶ÏÎ± to her. The general cause, denoted by Î½á½·ÎºÎ±Ï‚.. Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î½, is divided into two special cases; (1) a victory in war; (2) a victory in hunting. [This is simpler than to suppose that Î½á½·ÎºÎ±Ï‚..Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î½ refers to the withholding of a public offering,â€”which Ajax ought to have made on behalf of those who fought under his command; and that á¼Î½á½±ÏÏ‰Î½ refers to a private vow, which he had made on his own account. On this view, three different causes would be indicated; and á¼¦ Ï€Î¿Ï… in 176 would be disjunctive,â€”â€˜either, I ween,â€™â€”as it is in Od. 13. 234.]

Î½á½·ÎºÎ±Ï‚ á¼€Îºá½±ÏÏ€Ï‰Ï„Î¿Î½ Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î½=Î½á½·ÎºÎ±Ï‚..á¼€ÎºÎ±ÏÏ€á½½Ï„Î¿Ï… Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î½ ( Ant. 793 f. Î½Îµá¿–ÎºÎ¿Ï‚ á¼€Î½Î´Ïá¿¶Î½ Î¾á½»Î½Î±Î¹Î¼Î¿Î½): cp. I. T. 566 ÎºÎ±Îºá¿†Ï‚ Î³Ï…Î½Î±Î¹Îºá½¸Ï‚ Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î½ á¼„Ï‡Î±ÏÎ¹Î½ á¼€Ï€á½½Î»ÎµÏ„Î¿. Legg. p. 853 D á½§Î½ Î´á½´ Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î½ Î¿á½Îº á¼Ï€á½·Ï‡Î±ÏÎ¹Î½ Î»á½³Î³Î¿Î¹Î¼ á¼‚Î½..Î½á½¹Î¼Î¿Î½. á¼¤ á¿¥Î±: the disjunctive á¼¢ (or á¼¦=á¼ á½³) is rarely thus followed by á¿¥Î±. (Cp. 172 n.) For á¼¢ â€¦ Îµá¼´Ï„Îµ, cp. Eur. Alc. 114á¼¢ Î›Ï…Îºá½·Î±Ï‚ | Îµá¼´Ï„â€™ á¼Ï€á½¶ Ï„á½°Ï‚ á¼€Î½á½»Î´ÏÎ¿Ï…Ï‚ | á¼ˆÎ¼Î¼Ï‰Î½á½·Î´Î±Ï‚ á¼•Î´ÏÎ±Ï‚.

á¼¢..*Î¼á½´..; The reading of the MSS., á¼¢ Ï‡Î±Î»ÎºÎ¿Î¸á½½ÏÎ±Î¾ á¼¤ tin) *)enua/lios, was explained by supposing that Ï‡Î±Î»ÎºÎ¿Î¸á½½ÏÎ±Î¾ meant Ares, as distinguished from Enyalios (so the schol. here). How the second á¼¤ should be corrected, is uncertain. (1) In favour of Î¼á½µ, it may be noted that the interrogative Î¼á½µ is often followed, as here, by Ï„Î¹Ï‚, and that its tone of tentative suggestion is just in place. Cp. Od. 9. 405 f. á¼¦ Î¼á½µ Ï„á½·Ï‚ ÏƒÎµÎ¿ Î¼á¿†Î»Î± Î²ÏÎ¿Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼€á½³ÎºÎ¿Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á¼Î»Î±á½»Î½ÎµÎ¹; á¼¦ Î¼á½µ Ï„á½·Ï‚ Ïƒâ€™ Î±á½Ï„á½¸Î½ ÎºÏ„Îµá½·Î½ÎµÎ¹ Î´á½¹Î»á¿³ á¼ á½² Î²á½·Î·Ï†Î¹; O. C. 1502Î¼á½µ Ï„Î¹Ï‚ Î”Î¹á½¸Ï‚ ÎºÎµÏÎ±Ï…Î½á½¹Ï‚, á¼¤ Ï„Î¹Ï‚ á½€Î¼Î²Ïá½·Î± | Ï‡á½±Î»Î±Î¶) á¼Ï€Î¹ÏÏá½±Î¾Î±ÏƒÎ±; (2) Another possibility is Î´á½µ, as=â€˜thenâ€™ (to make a last guess). (3) ÏƒÎ¿á½· would be fitting, indeed, but would require us to suppose that the second á¼¤ in the MSS. is an inadvertent repetition of the first, not a corruption of some word like itself. (4) Îµá¼´ has also been suggested. But the implied construction, Î¼Î¿Î¼Ï†á½°Î½ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½, Îµá¼´ Ï„Î¹Î½) (Îµá¼¶Ï‡ÎµÎ½), would be too harsh. (5) á¼¦ is condemned by the fact that with Sophocles this interrogative á¼¦ regularly stands first in its clause; only a vocative sometimes precedes it: see on Ant. 1281.

á¼˜Î½Ï…á½±Î»Î¹Î¿Ï‚ is in the Iliad either the War-god (2. 651), seemingly identical with Ares, or an epithet of Ares (17. 211 á¼ŒÏÎ·Ï‚ | Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á½¸Ï‚ á¼Î½Ï…á½±Î»Î¹Î¿Ï‚). Like á¼˜Î½Ï…á½½, the word is of uncertain (possibly Thracian) origin. The mention of this deity has a two-fold fitness here; (1) on account of the reference in 178 to Artemis Agrotera; for, acc. to Pollux 8. 91, the Athenian Polemarch made annual offerings á¼ˆÏÏ„á½³Î¼Î¹Î´á¼° Î‘Î³ÏÎ¿Ï„á½³Ïá¾³ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á¿· á¼˜Î½Ï…Î±Î»á½·á¿³: (2) because in the island-home of Ajax there was a á¼±ÎµÏá½¹Î½ of Enyalios, founded by Solon to commemorate the victory by which Athens wrested Salamis from the Megarians ( Plut. Sol. 9). Further, Enyalios is here supposed to have helped Ajax; whereas Ares usually favoured the Trojans (cp. Il. 20. 38). As to the Attic relationship between the two deities, see Appendix.

á¼¥ÎºÎ¿Î¹ Î³á½°Ï á¼‚Î½, â€˜willâ€™ (or â€˜mustâ€™) â€˜comeâ€™: cp. 88 Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Î¹Î¼â€™ á¼„Î½. The Î³á½°Ï here refers to a thought implied in the last sentence:â€”â€˜You would never have done this thing of your own nature; (and if you have done it in madness, that proves nothing against your nature,) for heavensent madness cannot be helped; only, may the gods avert the evil rumour!â€™â€” i.e., â€˜may it prove to be false.â€™

From verse 172 down to this point, the Chorus have been asking whether the rumour can be true. Now they pass to the alternative:â€”â€˜But if it is untrue, then up and refute it.â€™

Î–Îµá½ºÏ‚ â€¦ Î¦Î¿á¿–Î²Î¿Ï‚. Both gods are averters of evil, á¼€Î»ÎµÎ¾á½·ÎºÎ±ÎºÎ¿Î¹, á¼€Ï€Î¿Ï„Ïá½¹Ï€Î±Î¹Î¿Î¹. But Zeus is invoked with especial fitness as being the source of mysterious voices and rumours ( Il. 8. 250á¼”Î½Î¸Î± Ï€Î±Î½Î¿Î¼Ï†Î±á½·á¿³ Î–Î·Î½á½¶ á¿¥á½³Î¶ÎµÏƒÎºÎ¿Î½ á¼ˆÏ‡Î±Î¹Î¿á½·).

Î¼á½µ, Î¼á½µ Î¼), á¼„Î½Î±Î¾. If Î¼) be sound, it can be only the acc.: an elision of Î¼Î¿Î¹ is impossible (see O. C. 1436, n. in Appendix). But this is certainly forced; and, though the Chorus afterwards speak of themselves as involved in their chief's peril (252 ff.), that thought is less fitting here.

The simplest remedy is that which is proposed by Prof. v. Wilamowitz-MÃ¶llendorff (cr. n.), who, referring to the hiatus after á¼„Î½Î± in 193, would here omit Î¼). The syllables Î¼á½µ, Î¼á½µ Î¼) answer metrically to Î¼Î¿Î¼Ï†á½°Î½ in 180, and we should thus have to suppose that Î¼á½µ, Î¼á½µ, á¼„Î½Î±Î¾ represents --u-. Such an hiatus seems a very doubtful one for tragic lyrics: otherwise the suggestion would be welcome, as Î¼á½µ, Î¼á½µ is supported by O. C. 210Î¼á½µ, Î¼á½µ Î¼â€™ á¼€Î½á½³Ïá¿ƒ. Morstadt's remedy, Î¼á½´ Î¼Î·Îºá½³Ï„), á½¦Î½Î±Î¾, (instead of Î¼á½µ, Î¼á½µ Î¼), á¼„Î½Î±Î¾, á¼”Î¸),) has found much favour, and is satisfactory in itself; but it does not account for the origin of the vulgate.

ÎºÎ»Î¹Ïƒá½·Î±Î¹Ï‚ á½„Î¼Î¼â€™ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½. The sense required is, â€˜keeping thy face hidden in the tentâ€™: so that ÎºÎ»Î¹Ïƒá½·Î±Î¹Ï‚ is a locative dat. The adv. á½§Î´) helps to suggest the idea of â€˜hidden.â€™ The objections to the version, â€˜keeping thine eyes fixed on the tents,â€™ are, (1) that á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½ could not well stand for á¼Ï€á½³Ï‡Ï‰Î½, and (2) that the seclusion of Ajax within his tent is not then expressed.â€” á¼„Ïá¿ƒ with Î± (=Î»á½½Î²Î±Î½ in 181), from á¼ Ïá½±Î¼Î·Î½: cp. 129, and see Appendix on 75.

Line 193

á¼„Î½Î±, the prep., with anastrophe, as=á¼€Î½á½±ÏƒÏ„Î·Î¸Î¹: the hiatus as in Il. 9. 247á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼„Î½Î±, Îµá¼° Î¼á½³Î¼Î¿Î½á½±Ï‚ Î³Îµ.

á½…Ï€Î¿Ï… â€¦ Ï€Î¿Ï„á½³, â€˜wheresoever,â€™ i.e. in whatever spot within the dwelling. The change of Ï€Î¿Ï„á½² to Ï€Î¿Ï„á½¶ (on which see Tr. 1214 n.) introduces a strange phrase, ÏƒÏ„Î·Ïá½·Î¶ÎµÎ¹ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ ÏƒÏ‡Î¿Î»á¿‡. The simple dat. (of circumstance) is clearly right.

á¼€Î³Ï‰Î½á½·á¿³ ÏƒÏ‡Î¿Î»á¾· seems to mean, â€˜battlepause,â€™ i.e., rest from battle. Other explanations are: (1) ÏƒÏ‡Î¿Î»á½µ which causes an á¼€Î³á½½Î½ (discrimen); because, while Ajax rests, his foes are perilously active. Now, if the Chorus assumed that Ajax, while absent from battle, had been employed in other effort, then, indeed, they might call his rest á¼€Î³á½½Î½Î¹Î¿Ï‚ ÏƒÏ‡Î¿Î»á½µ, â€˜a strenuous rest,â€™ like otium negotiosum. But it seems impossible that á¼€Î³á½½Î½Î¹Î¿Ï‚ ÏƒÏ‡Î¿Î»á½µ should mean merely, his â€˜perilousâ€™ or â€˜criticalâ€™ rest,â€”made so by the acts of others.

á¼Ï‡Î¸Ïá¿¶Î½ Î´â€™ á½•Î²ÏÎ¹Ï‚ á½§Î´â€™ á¼€Ï„á½±ÏÎ²Î·Ï„Î± ğŸ—©
Line 196

á¼€Ï„á½±ÏÎ²Î·Ï„Î±, neut. pl. as adverb. I keep this, the reading of the MSS., as Wecklein and Bellermann do. Dindorf strikes out á½§Î´) (unwarrantably), and writes á¼€Ï„á½±ÏÎ²Î·Ï„Î¿Ï‚. In an epode, the strophic test is absent, and the logaoedic metre admits of Dindorf's reading. There is, however, a point in favour of á¼€Ï„á½±ÏÎ²Î·Ï„Î± which deserves to be noted; viz., that the adverbial neut. pl., though it has no special relation to verbs of motion, is, in fact, very often joined with such verbs; and that the phrase á¼€Ï„á½±ÏÎ²Î·Ï„Î± á½ÏÎ¼á¾¶Ï„Î±Î¹ is therefore thoroughly consonant with poetical usage. See (e.g.) O. T. 883á½‘Ï€á½³ÏÎ¿Ï€Ï„Î± Ï€Î¿ÏÎµá½»ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹: O. C. 1695Î¿á½”Ï„Î¿Î¹ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½±Î¼ÎµÎ¼Ï€Ï„â€™ á¼”Î²Î·Ï„Î¿Î½: Il. 17. 75á¼€Îºá½·Ï‡Î·Ï„Î± Î´Î¹á½½ÎºÏ‰Î½ | á¼µÏ€Ï€Î¿Ï…Ï‚: Pind. O. 7. 45Î²Î±á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹..á¼€Ï„á½³ÎºÎ¼Î±ÏÏ„Î±: Soph. Ph. 1740á¼€Ï€Î±ÏÎ¸á½³Î½ÎµÏ…Ï„â€™ á¼€Î»Ï‰Î¼á½³Î½Î±: Eur. Bacch. 435Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼„ÎºÏÎ±Î½Î¸â€™ á½¡ÏÎ¼á½µÏƒÎ±Î¼ÎµÎ½. For the hiatus at the end of the verse, cp. 425 Ï‡Î¸Î¿Î½á½¸Ï‚ Î¼Î¿Î»á½¹Î½Ï„â€™ á¼€Ï€á½¸ | á¼™Î»Î»Î±Î½á½·Î´Î¿Ï‚.

Line 198

ÎºÎ±Î³Ï‡Î±Î¶á½¹Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½. Dindorf writes ÎºÎ±Ï‡Î±Î¶á½¹Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½, on the ground that the form ÎºÎ±Î³Ï‡á½±Î¶Ï‰ was not Attic. (His further change of Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½ into á¼Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½ is merely for the sake of equalising this v. with 197 f.) The main facts are these. 1. Aristophanes uses ÎºÎ±Ï‡á½±Î¶Ï‰Î½ once ( Eccl. 849), and also the noun ÎºÎ±Ï‡Î±ÏƒÎ¼á¿¶Î½ (Nub. 1073). 2. It is true that ÎºÎ±Î³Ï‡á½±Î¶Ï‰ cannot be proved by metre from any verse earlier than that of Babrius (100. 8 ÎºÎ±Î³Ï‡á½±ÏƒÎ±Ï‚), and Paulus Silentiarius (6th cent.) in Anth. Pal. 6. 74. 3 (ÎºÎ±Î³Ï‡á½±Î¶Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±). 3. On the other hand the MSS. have á¼€Î½ÎµÎºá½±Î³Ï‡Î±ÏƒÎµ in Plat. Rep. 337 A, and á¼€Î½Î±ÎºÎ±Î³Ï‡á½±ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ in Euthyd. 300 D; forms, be it noted, which carry their own commendation, since, in the compound with á¼€Î½á½±, the nasal (Î³ before Ï‡) makes pronunciation easier. 4. Lastly, there is the analogy of the Homeric ÎºÎ±Î³Ï‡Î±Î»á½±Ï‰. Surely, then, there is no reason to doubt that Sophocles could have used ÎºÎ±Î³Ï‡á½±Î¶Ï‰ if he found it metrically convenient.

Î²Î±ÏÏ…á½±Î»Î³Î·Ï„Î±. I follow the MSS. in leaving the hiatus (cp. 196), which here has the special justification of a pause, making it needless to write Î²Î±ÏÏ…Î±Î»Î³á½µÏ„Ï‰Ï‚ with Dindorf. That the scholiast in L, like the MSS., had the neut. pl., appears from his paraphrase, Î²Î±Ïá½³Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼€Î»Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½á½±. Some editors prefer to write Î²Î±ÏÏ…á½±Î»Î³Î·Ï„), which is also metrically possible. The sense is, â€˜fraught with heavy painâ€™ to us; the á¼„Î»Î³Î¿Ï‚ is not the bitter indignation felt by the Greeks. The word occurs only here: and Î²Î±ÏÏ…Î±Î»Î³á½µÏ‚ is post-classical.

Salamis is in this play a kingdom independent of Athens, but the Salaminians are of Athenian stock, and revere â€˜sacred Athensâ€™ (1222) as the metropolis of their race. See Introduction, Â§ 4.

Ï„á½· Î´á½² Î²á½±ÏÎ¿Ï‚ á¼Î½á½µÎ»Î»Î±ÎºÏ„Î±Î¹ Î½á½ºÎ¾ á¼¥Î´Îµ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ á¼¡Î¼ÎµÏá½·Î±Ï‚; â€˜And what heaviness (heavy trouble) has the past night received in exchange for the (already grievous) fortune of the day?â€™ á¼Î½á½µÎ»Î»Î±ÎºÏ„Î±Î¹ in a midd. sense; cp. Diod. frag. 60 á¼Î³á½³Î½ÎµÏ„Î¿ Î²Î±Ïƒá½·Î»Î¹ÏƒÏƒÎ± á¼°Î´Î¹Ï‰Ï„Î¹Îºá¿†Ï‚ á¼‘ÏƒÏ„á½·Î±Ï‚ á¼Î¾Î·Î»Î»Î±Î³Î¼á½³Î½Î· á¼¡Î³ÎµÎ¼Î¿Î½á½·Î±Î½. The fact that á¼¤Î»Î»Î±Î³Î¼Î±Î¹ has more often a passive sense in Attic is quite compatible with such an exceptional use; thus Antiphon can say, Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï€Î»Î¿á¿¦Î½ Ï€ÎµÏ€Î¿Î¹Î·Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚ (or. 5 Â§ 21), and Ï„ÎµÏ„Î¹Î¼Ï‰ÏÎ·Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚ á¼‘Î±Ï…Ï„á½¹Î½ ( Î². Î². Â§ 8). But it is more doubtful whether such a notion as Î¼Î¿á½·ÏÎ±Ï‚, Ï€Ïá½±Î¾ÎµÏ‰Ï‚, or ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±ÏƒÏ„á½±ÏƒÎµÏ‰Ï‚ can here be supplied with Ï„á¿†Ï‚ á¼¡Î¼ÎµÏá½·Î±Ï‚. The parallels adduced are such as á¼¡ á¼‘á¿´Î±, á¼¡ á¼‘Ï‰Î¸Î¹Î½á½µ, á¼¡ á½€Ïˆá½·Î±, á¼¡ Ï€ÏÏ‰á¿“Î±, Ï„á½´Î½ Î¸ÎµÏÎµá½·Î·Î½ (â€˜in summer,â€™ Her. 1. 189), Ï„á½´Î½ Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î¼ÎµÏÎ¹Î½á½µÎ½ (id. 1. 202). There was indeed a tendency in Greek idiom to make substantives out of fem. adjectives; i.e. to use the fem. adj. alone, whenever the subst. (such as Î³á¿†, á½Î´á½¹Ï‚, á½¥ÏÎ±, Î¼Î¿á¿–ÏÎ±, Î´á½·ÎºÎ·) could readily be understood. And that tendency must be considered here.

No tolerable emendation has been made. á¼ ÏÎµÎ¼á½·Î±Ï‚, â€˜stillness,â€™ though possible, is very feeble. Îµá½Î¼Î±Ïá½·Î±Ï‚ (=Îµá½Î¼Î±ÏÎµá½·Î±Ï‚), which Nauck adopts, is directly contrary to the sense; for, even before the dread rumour arose, the Chorus had been disquieted by the long seclusion and inaction of Ajax (194 f.). á¼€Î¼Î¼Î¿Ïá½·Î±Ï‚, without some further definition (such as Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Ï€Ïá½¶Î½), would be too vague. And the words Î½á½ºÎ¾ á¼¥Î´Îµ suggest that there was some mention of day. On the whole, the traditional reading, though difficult, is less open to objection than any remedy which has been proposed.

The schol. in L has: Î³Ï. Î´á½² á¼€Î·Î¼ÎµÏá½·Î±Ï‚ á¼€Î½Ï„á½¶ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ á¼€Î·Î´Î¿á¿¦Ï‚ Ï†Î¿Ïá¾¶Ï‚ (â€˜unpleasant courseâ€™), ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¹ á½ Î½Î¿á¿¦Ï‚, Ï€Î¿á¿–Î¿Î½ Î²á½±ÏÎ¿Ï‚ á¼”Î»Î±Î²ÎµÎ½ Î±á½•Ï„Î· á¼¡ Î½á½ºÎ¾ á¼€Ï€á½¸ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï„á½³ÏÎ±Ï‚ á¼€Î·Î´á½·Î±Ï‚; This explanation of á¼€Î·Î¼ÎµÏá½·Î±Ï‚ by á¼€Î·Î´Î¿á¿¦Ï‚ Ï†Î¿Ïá¾¶Ï‚ and á¼€Î·Î´á½·Î±Ï‚ indicates (I think) a reference, not to á¼¡Î¼á½³ÏÎ±â€”as if á¼€Î·Î¼ÎµÏá½·Î± could mean Î´Ï…ÏƒÎ·Î¼ÎµÏá½·Î±â€”but to á¼¥Î¼ÎµÏÎ¿Ï‚: the original scholium may have had á¼€Î½Î·Î¼ÎµÏá½·Î±Ï‚ (meant as â€˜unkindly fortuneâ€™).

á¼±Ï€Ï€Î¿Î½á½½Î¼Î±Ï‚, â€˜guiding horses,â€™ refers to riding in both the other places where it occurs ( Eur. Hipp. 1399, of Hippolytus; Nub. 571, of Poseidon Hippius). Here, Î²Î¿Ï„á¿†ÏÎ±Ï‚, closely following Î²Î¿Ï„á½±, must mean the herdsmen who tended the sheep and oxen (=Ï€Î¿Î¹Î¼Î½á½·Ï‰Î½ á¼Ï€Î¹ÏƒÏ„á½±Ï„Î±Î¹Ï‚, 27). It would be forced, then, to suppose that á¼±Ï€Ï€Î¿Î½á½½Î¼Î±Ï‚ means â€˜tending horses,â€™â€”with ref. to the horses of the Greeks on the Î»ÎµÎ¹Î¼á½¼Î½ á¼±Ï€Ï€Î¿Î¼Î±Î½á½µÏ‚ (143 f.). That would be as if one said, â€˜the cattle, and their herdsmen, who also tended horses.â€™ Herdsmen in charge of great flocks and herds, on a wide plain, and near a watchful foe, might well be mounted. It is no objectionâ€” and least of all, in an Attic tragedyâ€” that the Homeric warrior does not ride. â€”The reading á¼±Ï€Ï€Î¿Î½á½½Î¼Î±Ï‚, instead of á¼±Ï€Ï€Î¿Î½á½¹Î¼Î¿Ï…Ï‚ (â€˜horse-feedingâ€™), is made certain by metre (v. 245), and is confirmed by the first hand in L (cr. n.).

á½§Î½ (neut.), instead of á¼§Ï‚, since Ï€Î¿á½·Î¼Î½Î·Î½ is a â€˜noun of multitudeâ€™; cp. O. C. 1070á¼„Î¼Î²Î±ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚, Î¿á¼³ Îº.Ï„.Î». (n.). Then Ï„á½´Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ (sc. á¼”ÏƒÏ‰, â€˜within the house,â€™ refers to all the incidents that followed his arrival (á¼¤Î»Ï…Î¸Îµ). Schneidewin wrongly joins á¼”ÏƒÏ‰ ÏƒÏ†á½±Î¶Îµ (â€˜stach totâ€™), comparing Aesch. Ï€Î»ÎµÏ…ÏÎ¿ÎºÎ¿Ï€á¿¶Î½, slashing at their sides with his sword: a compound like Î¸Î±Î»Î±Ï„Ï„Î¿ÎºÎ¿Ï€Îµá¿–Î½ ( Ar. Eq. 830), Î¼ÎµÏ„ÎµÏ‰ÏÎ¿ÎºÎ¿Ï€Îµá¿–Î½ ( Ar. Pax 92).

Ï„á½° Î´á½² Ï€Î»ÎµÏ…ÏÎ¿ÎºÎ¿Ï€á¿¶Î½ Î´á½·Ï‡â€™ á¼€Î½ÎµÏÏá½µÎ³Î½Ï….
Î´á½»Î¿ Î´â€™ á¼€ÏÎ³á½·Ï€Î¿Î´Î±Ï‚ ÎºÏÎ¹Î¿á½ºÏ‚ á¼€Î½ÎµÎ»á½¼Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 237

á¼€ÏÎ³á½·Ï€Î¿Î´Î±Ï‚: for the rt. ARG, denoting â€˜brightness,â€™ and its derivatives, cp. O. C. 670 n. As Ajax purposed to flog Odysseus (110), the ram which suffers that fate here might naturally be identified with him. The first ram, which is beheaded at once, might then represent Agamemnon; and MenelaÃ¼s would here be ignored. On this view, however, there is a discrepancy with verses 97â€”110, since both the Atreidae are there supposed to be dead, while Odysseus has still to suffer. Here one ram (Agamemnon) is slain, and the other (Odysseus) flogged, in rapid succession.

If the two rams are the two Atreidae, then Odysseus is ignored here. This would be consistent both with vv. 97â€” 110 and with 298â€”306. The flogging of the second ram here would correspond with the words Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ Î´á½² Î´ÎµÏƒÎ¼á½·Î¿Ï…Ï‚ | á¾Îºá½·Î¶ÎµÎ¸) in 299 f. Then came the colloquy of Ajax with Athena (301); after which, he slowly regained his sanity,â€”before he had inflicted the lash upon Odysseus. That the â€˜two ramsâ€™ are here the royal brethren might be suggested by the analogy of the two eagles in Ag. 115.On the other hand, the special ferocity with which Ajax treats the second ram rather indicates that it represents Odysseus. There would be no point in so distinguishing MenelaÃ¼s from Agamemnon. On the whole, it seems most probable that the poet meant Agamemnon and Odysseus, but was careless of strict consistency with vv. 97â€”110.

Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î¼á½²Î½ ÎºÎµÏ†Î±Î»á½´Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î³Î»á¿¶ÏƒÏƒÎ±Î½ á¼„ÎºÏÎ±Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 238

ÎºÎµÏ†Î±Î»á½´Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î³Î»á¿¶ÏƒÏƒÎ±Î½ á¼„ÎºÏÎ±Î½. He first shears off the head; then, still holding it, while the carcass drops to the ground, cuts off the end of the tongue; and next hurls both head and tongue from him. á¼„ÎºÏÎ± Î³Î»á¿¶ÏƒÏƒÎ± can mean the extremity, the tip, of the tongue, as in Theocr. 9. 30 á¼Ï€á½¶ Î³Î»á½½ÏƒÏƒÎ±Ï‚ á¼„ÎºÏÎ±Ï‚: so in Ph. 748á¼„ÎºÏÎ¿Î½ Ï€á½¹Î´Î± is the heel. It could not mean, â€˜the tongue from the roots,â€™ Î³Î»á¿¶ÏƒÏƒÎ±Î½ Ï€ÏÏ…Î¼Î½á½µÎ½ ( Il. 5. 292).â€”It was customary to cut out the tongues of animals slain for sacrifice, and to offer them separately ( Od. 3. 332: Ar. Pax 1060). But I doubt whether there is any reference here to the sacrificial custom; the act of Ajax rather expresses merely fierce hatred of a slanderer.

á¿¥Î¹Ï€Ï„Îµá¿– has the support of the MSS., not only here, but also in Ant. 131, Tr. 780.In the latter place, it is confirmed by Athenaeus p. 65 F, for he has á¿¥Î¹Ï€Ï„Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î± in his paraphrase. á¿¥Î¹Ï€Ï„Îµá¿–Î½, used only in pres. and impf., was current in Attic ( Ar. á¼¤Î´Î· Ï„Î¿Î¹ ÎºÏá¾¶Ï„Î±. The reading of the best MSS., both here and in the strophe (221 f.), can be retained, if in the strophe we make the slight change of á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½¸Ï‚ to á¼€Î½á½³ÏÎ¿Ï‚. á¼Ïá½³ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½, â€˜ply,â€™â€”properly, to ply the oar; then, to put anything in lively motion; Ant. 158Î¼á¿†Ï„Î¹Î½ á¼Ïá½³ÏƒÏƒÏ‰Î½, â€˜revolvingâ€™ thoughts in the mind. The accus. is, in the first place, object to Ï€ÎµÏ†á½¹Î²Î·Î¼Î±Î¹, but is felt also as a cognate acc. to Î¾Ï…Î½Î±Î»Î³Îµá¿–Î½ (like á¼„Î»Î³Î¿Ï‚ á¼€Î»Î³á¿¶), and could be, further, an acc. of the inner object with Ï„Ï…Ï€Îµá½·Ï‚ ( Il. 24. 420á¼•Î»ÎºÎµÎ±... á½…ÏƒÏƒâ€™ á¼Ï„á½»Ï€Î·): it is one of those cumulative constructions which Greek idiom (esp. in poetry) favours. Note that a simple inf. after Ï†Î¿Î²Î¿á¿¦Î¼Î±Î¹ usu. denotes what one is afraid to do ( Aesch. Ch. 46Ï†Î¿Î²Î¿á¿¦Î¼Î±Î¹ Î´â€™ á¼”Ï€Î¿Ï‚ Ï„á½¹Î´â€™ á¼ÎºÎ²Î±Î»Îµá¿–Î½), but can also denote what one fears to suffer: Plat. Phaedop. 68 E Ï†Î¿Î²Î¿á½»Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î¹..á¼¡Î´Î¿Î½á¿¶Î½ ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏÎ·Î¸á¿†Î½Î±Î¹.

Î±á¼¶Ïƒâ€™ á¼„Ï€Î»Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚, a fate such that no one can approach him, or stand at his side, without being involved in his doom. The Nemean lion is á¼„Ï€Î»Î±Ï„Î¿Î½ Î¸Ïá½³Î¼Î¼Î±, Tr. 1093.

The words Î»Î±Î¼Ï€Ïá¾¶Ï‚ á¼„Ï„ÎµÏ ÏƒÏ„ÎµÏÎ¿Ï€á¿†Ï‚ go with Î»á½µÎ³ÎµÎ¹, not with á¾„Î¾Î±Ï‚: they stand first, because they express the foremost thought,â€”viz., that the violence of his frenzy is past. â€˜Attended by the lightning-flash no more, the storm in his soul is subsiding, after a sharp outburst (á¾„Î¾Î±Ï‚ á½€Î¾á½»Ï‚), like the wind of the south.â€™ A key to these much-discussed verses may be found, I think, in a passage which seems to have been overlooked. The Greeks had observed that, when the Îá½¹Ï„Î¿Ï‚ was a stormy wind, it was accompanied by clouds; but, when gentler, by a clear sky: Problem. 26. 20 (p. 942 a 34) á½ Î½á½¹Ï„Î¿Ï‚, á½…Ï„Î±Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ á¼Î»á½±Ï„Ï„Ï‰Î½ á¾–, Î±á¼´Î¸ÏÎ¹á½¹Ï‚ á¼ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½, á½…Ï„Î±Î½ Î´á½² Î¼á½³Î³Î±Ï‚, Î½ÎµÏ†á½½Î´Î·Ï‚. Compare the description of the mad Ajax by ArctÃ®nus in the Iliupersis (ap. Î´á½³Î´Î¿Î¹ÎºÎ± Î¼á½´ â€¦ á¼¥Îºá¿ƒ. Though á¼¥ÎºÎµÎ¹ is tenable (â€˜I fear that it certainly has comeâ€™), á¼¥Îºá¿ƒ seems better, since there is still a real uncertainty and anxiety in their minds. See on El. 580.ï¼ˆá¼¥ÎºÎ¿Î¹, which was the common reading, is of course impossible here.)

Ï€á¿¶Ï‚ Î³á½±Ï, sc. á¼„Î»Î»Ï‰Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹; Normally, Ï€á¿¶Ï‚ Î³á½±Ï follows a negative statement, as in El. 911Î¿á½Î´â€™ Î±á½– Ïƒá½»Â· Ï€á¿¶Ï‚ Î³á½±Ï; (sc. á¼”Î´ÏÎ±ÏƒÎ±Ï‚): while Ï€á¿¶Ï‚ Î³á½°Ï Î¿á½” follows an affirmative, as ib. 1307 Î¿á¼¶ÏƒÎ¸Î± Î¼á½²Î½ Ï„á¼€Î½Î¸á½³Î½Î´Îµ, Ï€á¿¶Ï‚ Î³á½°Ï Î¿á½”; The use of Ï€á¿¶Ï‚ Î³á½±Ï here is thus peculiar, though the sense is clear.

Îµá¼° Ï€ÎµÏ€Î±Ï…Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚ Îº.Ï„.Î». The fact that despair has succeeded to frenzy argues that he is under the spell of some angry god. When the malady passed away, his mind ought to have recovered a healthy tone. They had already hinted at a Î¸Îµá½·Î± Î½á½¹ÏƒÎ¿Ï‚ as a possibility (186).

á½¡Ï‚ á½§Î´â€™ á¼Ï‡á½¹Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½ Îº.Ï„.Î».: á½¡Ï‚ marks the point of view to be taken: the gen. abs. presents the state of the facts as the condition under which one's opinion must be formed. Cp. Line 301

á½‘Ï€á¾´Î¾Î±Ï‚ is not a certain reading here; but (despite the fact that the first hand in L wrote á¼€Ï€á¾¶Î¾Î±Ï‚) it has, on the whole, at least as good authority as á¼€Ï€á¾´Î¾Î±Ï‚. The latter makes good sense enough, â€˜rushing away from meâ€™; but á½‘Ï€á¾´Î¾Î±Ï‚, expressing the sudden rush forward, as if towards something which had suddenly caught his attention, adds a picturesque touch which is absent from the other reading. For this sense of á½‘Ï€á½¹ in comp., cp. á½‘Ï€á½±Î³Ï‰, etc. The third possibility, á¼Ï€á¾´Î¾Î±Ï‚, would properly denote a rush onwards in a direction which had already been taken; and is thus less fitting here.

ÏƒÎºÎ¹á¾· Ï„Î¹Î½á½¶: Tecmessa, of course, followed Ajax to the door, but Athena was invisible to her: see on 15. Ajax seemed to speak with some phantom,â€”some creature of his brain.

Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Ï…Ï‚ á¼€Î½á½³ÏƒÏ€Î±; the phrase denotes the abrupt, spasmodic manner in which his words were jerked forth. They were wild and incoherent (21â€”116). Cp. Plat. Ï„Î±á¿¦ÏÎ¿Ï‚ á½£Ï‚ Î²ÏÏ…Ï‡á½½Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚: Theog. 832 Ï„Î±á¿¦ÏÎ¿Ï‚ á¼ÏÎ¹Î²Ïá½»Ï‡Î·Ï‚. á½¥Ï‚ Ï„Î¹ Î´ÏÎ±ÏƒÎµá½·Ï‰Î½, instead of Î´ÏÎ±ÏƒÎµá½·Ï‰Î½ Ï„Î¹ simply: cp. O. C. 630 á½¡Ï‚ Ï„ÎµÎ»á¿¶Î½ á¼Ï†Î±á½·Î½ÎµÏ„Î¿: Xen. An. 1. 5. 9Î´á¿†Î»Î¿Ï‚ á¼¦Î½ Îšá¿¦ÏÎ¿Ï‚ á½¡Ï‚ ÏƒÏ€Îµá½»Î´Ï‰Î½: Lys. or. 12 Â§ 90 Î´á¿†Î»Î¿Î¹ á¼”ÏƒÎµÏƒÎ¸Îµ á½¡Ï‚ á½€ÏÎ³Î¹Î¶á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î¹.

Ï„Î¿Î¹Î±á¿¦Ï„Î± Î³á½±Ï Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹ Îºá½ Î´á½»ÏÎµÏ„Î±Î¹. ğŸ—©
Line 327

Ï„Î¿Î¹Î±á¿¦Ï„Î± is qualified by Ï€Ï‰Ï‚: something in his utterances, which she cannot define, suggests this. Cp. Xen. Cyr. 3. 3. 7á¼”Î»ÎµÎ¾ÎµÎ½ á½§Î´á½³ Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ Îµá¼°Ï‚ Ï„á½¸ Î¼á½³ÏƒÎ¿Î½.

ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹ Îºá½ Î´á½»ÏÎµÏ„Î±Î¹. The word á¼¥ÏƒÏ…Ï‡Î¿Ï‚ in 325 does not imply silence; it contrasts the quietness of his present demeanour with his former frenzy, and with the first vehemence (317) of his grief. His occasional words, or laments (such as á¼°á½½ Î¼Î¿á½· Î¼Î¿Î¹, 333), are in a tone which foreshadows the worst.

The verse is rejected by Nauck and others as though it were inconsistent with v. 325, and had been patched up from v. 383. There is no ground for this view. On the other hand, after á¼¥ÏƒÏ…Ï‡Î¿Ï‚ in 325, the fear expressed in 326 would be unintelligible, if no reason were subjoined. Bergk, who joins in condemning the verse, allows that Sophocles is usually careful of logical coherence in drama (â€˜pflegt .. sorgfÃ¤ltig zu motivirenâ€™); but suggests that here the neglect of it might be â€˜a mark of the archaic styleâ€™ (Jahr. f. Class. Phil. 97. 378).

Ï€Î±Ïá½½Î½, being, as he is, in the presence of his own handiwork. The implied antithesis is with what he might feel if told of things which he had done elsewhere, but which he could not see. Cp. 1131, 1156.

Line 339

á¼°á½¼ Ï€Î±á¿– Ï€Î±á¿–. One of the signs that he is resolved to die is the way in which his thoughts dwell upon his son; he cannot rest till he sees him (530â€”544). The child is the heir of his fame, and may live to clear it of the stain (556 f.). As Eurysaces is not at once brought to him, he next cries (342), Î¤Îµá¿¦ÎºÏÎ¿Î½ ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶: Teucer is his second thought, for to Teucer he will commit the care of his son (562).

á½¤Î¼Î¿Î¹ Ï„á½±Î»Î±Î¹Î½): the nom. as in 800, El. 788, and oft.

Î•á½Ïá½»ÏƒÎ±ÎºÎµÏ‚, so named from the shield of Ajax (19): cp. 574 n. The first syll. of a dactyl in the third foot is usually either the last syllable of a word, or else a monosyllable; but proper names are exempt from the rule.

345 Ï„á½±Ï‡â€™ á¼„Î½ Ï„Î¹Î½â€™ Î±á¼°Î´á¿¶ Îºá¼€Ï€â€™ á¼Î¼Î¿á½¶ Î²Î»á½³ÏˆÎ±Ï‚ Î»á½±Î²Î¿Î¹.

Line 346

Î´Î¹Î¿á½·Î³Ï‰: cp. O. T. 1287Î´Î¹Î¿á½·Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½ ÎºÎ»á¿‡Î¸ÏÎ±, and ib. 1295.

Ï€Ïá½±Î³Î·, deeds: cp. 21.

The á¼ÎºÎºá½»ÎºÎ»Î·Î¼Î± is now pushed on through the central door. It was a small stage, but large enough to allow of Ajax being shown surrounded by some of the slaughtered animals. The word Ï€Ïá½±Î³Î· in 347, and the language of vv. 351 ff., show that the carnage was represented. The other plays in which Soph <*>es has used the eccyclema are the Antigone (1294, where see n.), and the Electra (1464 f., n.).

Ajax, sitting among his victims, and meditating his own destruction, was the subject of a famous picture by Timomachus of Byzantium. Philostratus (Vit. Apoll. 2. 22 Â§ 5) thus describes it: Ï„á½¸Î½ Î‘á¼´Î±Î½Ï„Î± Ï„á½¸Î½ Î¤Î¹Î¼Î¿Î¼á½±Ï‡Î¿Ï…..á¼€Ï€ÎµÎºÏ„Î¿Î½á½¹Ï„Î± Ï„á¼€Î½ Ï„á¿‡ Î¤ÏÎ¿á½·á¾³ Î²Î¿Ï…Îºá½¹Î»Î¹Î± ÎºÎ±Î¸á¿†ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ á¼€Ï€ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ·Îºá½¹Ï„Î± [cp. v. 325 á¼¥ÏƒÏ…Ï‡Î¿Ï‚ Î¸Î±ÎºÎµá¿–], Î²Î¿Ï…Î»á½´Î½ Ï€Î¿Î¹Î¿á½»Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼‘Î±Ï…Ï„á½¸Î½ Î´Î¹Î±Ï†Î¸Îµá¿–ÏÎ±Î¹. The picture was at Cyzicus in 70 B.C. ( Cic. In Verr. 2. 4. 60), but was afterwards bought by Julius Caesar for the Temple of Venus Genetrix in Rome ( N. H. 7. 38 Â§ 126). See Introduction Â§ 20.

Ï„á½° Ï„Î¿á¿¦Î´Îµ Ï€Ïá½±Î³Î·, ÎºÎ±á½Ï„á½¸Ï‚ á½¡Ï‚ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½ ÎºÏ…ÏÎµá¿–.
Î‘á¼´. á¼°á½¼ ğŸ—©
Line 348348-429

This kommos serves, like the last (201â€”262), as a lyric expression of tragic pathos; after which the situation is further developed, as in the former case, by iambic dialogue. But in one respect this kommos differs from its predecessor. In order to bring the mind of Ajax into fuller relief, the lyrics are given to him alone, while the Chorus and Tecmessa speak only trimeters.

The structure is as follows:â€”1st strophe 348â€”355=1st antistr. 356â€”363: 2nd str. 364â€”378=2nd ant. 379â€”393: 3rd str. 394â€”411=3rd ant. 412â€”429. For the metres see Metrical Analysis.

á¼°á½¼ Ï†á½·Î»Î¿Î¹ Î½Î±Ï…Î²á½±Ï„Î±Î¹: his first words mark the affection which was so deep in the rugged nature.

á½€ÏÎ¸á¿· Î½á½¹Î¼á¿³, the right, sound rule of loyalty to friendshipâ€”which the Greek chiefs have forsaken.

á¼€Î¼Ï†á½·Î´ÏÎ¿Î¼Î¿Î½, â€˜running aroundâ€™ me.â€” ÎºÏ…ÎºÎ»Îµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹: this rare midd. is read in Her. 8. 16, Î¼Î·Î½Î¿ÎµÎ¹Î´á½²Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Î¹á½µÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚ Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î½Îµá¿¶Î½ á¼ÎºÏ…ÎºÎ»Îµá¿¦Î½Ï„Î¿ á½¡Ï‚ Ï€ÎµÏÎ¹Î»á½±Î²Î¿Î¹ÎµÎ½ Î±á½Ï„Î¿á½»Ï‚. ÎºÏ…ÎºÎ»Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î±Î¹ would be the more usual midd. form ( Her. 3. 157, and oft.).

á¼Ï€â€™ á¼Î¾ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ³Î±ÏƒÎ¼á½³Î½Î¿Î¹Ï‚: á¼Ï€á½¶ denotes the condition: Aesch. Ag. 1379á¼•ÏƒÏ„Î·ÎºÎ± Î´â€™ á¼”Î½Î¸â€™ á¼”Ï€Î±Î¹Ïƒâ€™ á¼Ï€) á¼Î¾ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ³Î±ÏƒÎ¼á½³Î½Î¿Î¹Ï‚. (The phrase occurs also in Aesch. Pers. 525.) Cp. Soph. Ant. 556á¼Ï€â€™ á¼€ÏÏá½µÏ„Î¿Î¹Ï‚..Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ á¼Î¼Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î¹Ï‚ (n.).

Î¿á½Îº á¼‚Î½ Î³á½³Î½Î¿Î¹Ï„Î¿ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Î¸), á½…Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ á¼Î³á½¼ â€¦ | â€¦ Î¿á½ Ï†Î±Î½á¿¶ Ï„Î¿á½Î¼á½¸Î½ Î³á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚. In other words, the constr. would be plain if á½…Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ were struck out. For the sentiment, cp. Tr. 742Ï„á½¸ Î³á½°Ï | Ï†Î±Î½Î¸á½²Î½ Ï„á½·Ï‚ á¼‚Î½ Î´á½»Î½Î±Î¹Ï„â€™ á¼‚Î½ á¼€Î³á½³Î½Î·Ï„Î¿Î½ Ï€Î¿Îµá¿–Î½; (n.).

Î¿á½ Î³á½°Ï Î³á½³Î½Î¿Î¹Ï„â€™ á¼‚Î½ Ï„Î±á¿¦Î¸â€™ á½…Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ Î¿á½Ï‡ á½§Î´â€™ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½.
Î‘á¼´. á¼°á½¼ Ï€á½±Î½Î¸â€™ á½Ïá¿¶Î½ á¼Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½ Ï„â€™ á¼€Îµá½¶ ğŸ—©
Line 379

Ï€á½±Î½Î¸â€™ á½Ïá¿¶Î½: as Philoctetes says to Odysseus, Ph. 1013á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼¡ ÎºÎ±Îºá½´ Ïƒá½´ Î´Î¹á½° Î¼Ï…Ï‡á¿¶Î½ Î²Î»á½³Ï€Î¿Ï…Ïƒâ€™ á¼€Îµá½¶ | ÏˆÏ…Ï‡á½µ Îº.Ï„.Î»., â€˜thy base soul, ever peering from some ambush.â€™ The conjecture Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î± Î´Ïá¿¶Î½ is not only weak, but incorrect, since the sense would require Ï€á¾¶Î½ Î´Ïá¿¶Î½.

á¼Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½ Ï„). Îµá¼° Ï„á½° Î¼á½²Î½ Ï†Î¸á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹ Îº.Ï„.Î». The conjectures of various critics are recorded and classified in the Appendix. Here I will briefly state what seem the main points of the problem.

(1) The antistrophic verses, 423â€”427 (á¼Î¾ÎµÏá¿¶...Ï€Ïá½¹ÎºÎµÎ¹Î¼Î±Î¹), appear sound. The changes which have been proposed in them have all been designed to suit some emendation in 405 ff., and would have no probability if verses 423 ff. were considered simply on their own merits.

(2) There is only one real discrepancy of metre between the traditional text here and that of the antistrophe; viz., that Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´) in 406 answers to the Ï„Î¹Î½Î± of Î¿á½”Ï„Î¹Î½Î± in 424, where the Î±, being the last syllable of a verse, could be either long or short, and is here long. (Some, indeed, read Î¿á½”Ï„Î¹Î½â€™ á¼: cr. n.) That is, instead of Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´), we require u-. As to á¼Î¾ÎµÏá½³Ï‰ in 423, answering to Îµá¼° Ï„á½° Î¼á½²Î½ in 405, we should write á¼Î¾ÎµÏá¿¶. With regard to the diction of 405 ff., the most suspicious point is the redundancy á½Î¼Î¿á¿¦ Ï€á½³Î»Î±Ï‚, suggesting that one of the words was a gloss upon the other.

(3) If, then, we assume that the antistrophe is sound, we may conclude that the fault in the strophe lies within the words Îµá¼° Ï„á½° Î¼á½²Î½ Ï†Î¸á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹, Ï†á½·Î»Î¿Î¹, Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´â€™ á½Î¼Î¿á¿¦ Ï€á½³Î»Î±Ï‚. A very slight change will restore the metre, viz. Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´) for Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´): cp. the words of Ajax in 453 á½¥ÏƒÏ„â€™ á¼Î½ Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´Îµ Ï‡Îµá¿–ÏÎ±Ï‚ Î±á¼±Î¼á½±Î¾Î±Î¹ Î²Î¿Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚. There he points to the slain cattle around him; and so he probably does here also. We could then understand the sense to be: â€˜If those things (Ï„á½° Î¼á½²Î½, his glories in the past) perish, my friends, á½Î¼Î¿á¿¦ Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´Îµ, along with (i.e., by the slaughter of) such creatures, Ï€á½³Î»Î±Ï‚, near me there.â€™ But Ï€á½³Î»Î±Ï‚ may have been a marginal gloss (on á½Î¼Î¿á¿¦), which has displaced some other word: e.g., the poet may have written Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´â€™ á½Î¼Î¿á¿¦ Î²Î¿Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ (cp. v. 453).

(4) Whatever may have been the original form of the words Îµá¼° Ï„á½° Î¼á½²Î½ Ï†Î¸á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹, Ï†á½·Î»Î¿Î¹, Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´â€™ á½Î¼Î¿á¿¦ Ï€á½³Î»Î±Ï‚, it is at least highly probable that their general sense was, â€˜If my old renown is perishing.â€™ This is suggested by the other passages where we find the same sequence of ideas,â€”i.e., the thought of his past glory closely followed by that of his present disgrace; see (1) 421â€”427: (2) 437â€”456: (3) 612â€”621.

(5) Those who believe that the antistrophic verses 423â€”427 are corrupt have a freer hand for emendation here; and, as will be seen in the Appendix, some of the proposed restorations have been very bold. But such remedies pass into the region of pure guess-work.

405 Îµá¼° Ï„á½° Î¼á½²Î½ Ï†Î¸á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹, Ï†á½·Î»Î¿Î¹, Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´â€™ ğŸ—©
Line 405Line 405

Îµá¼° Ï„á½° Î¼á½²Î½ Ï†Î¸á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹ Îº.Ï„.Î». The conjectures of various critics are recorded and classified in the Appendix. Here I will briefly state what seem the main points of the problem.

(1) The antistrophic verses, 423â€”427 (á¼Î¾ÎµÏá¿¶...Ï€Ïá½¹ÎºÎµÎ¹Î¼Î±Î¹), appear sound. The changes which have been proposed in them have all been designed to suit some emendation in 405 ff., and would have no probability if verses 423 ff. were considered simply on their own merits.

(2) There is only one real discrepancy of metre between the traditional text here and that of the antistrophe; viz., that Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´) in 406 answers to the Ï„Î¹Î½Î± of Î¿á½”Ï„Î¹Î½Î± in 424, where the Î±, being the last syllable of a verse, could be either long or short, and is here long. (Some, indeed, read Î¿á½”Ï„Î¹Î½â€™ á¼: cr. n.) That is, instead of Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´), we require u-. As to á¼Î¾ÎµÏá½³Ï‰ in 423, answering to Îµá¼° Ï„á½° Î¼á½²Î½ in 405, we should write á¼Î¾ÎµÏá¿¶. With regard to the diction of 405 ff., the most suspicious point is the redundancy á½Î¼Î¿á¿¦ Ï€á½³Î»Î±Ï‚, suggesting that one of the words was a gloss upon the other.

(3) If, then, we assume that the antistrophe is sound, we may conclude that the fault in the strophe lies within the words Îµá¼° Ï„á½° Î¼á½²Î½ Ï†Î¸á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹, Ï†á½·Î»Î¿Î¹, Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´â€™ á½Î¼Î¿á¿¦ Ï€á½³Î»Î±Ï‚. A very slight change will restore the metre, viz. Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´) for Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´): cp. the words of Ajax in 453 á½¥ÏƒÏ„â€™ á¼Î½ Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´Îµ Ï‡Îµá¿–ÏÎ±Ï‚ Î±á¼±Î¼á½±Î¾Î±Î¹ Î²Î¿Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚. There he points to the slain cattle around him; and so he probably does here also. We could then understand the sense to be: â€˜If those things (Ï„á½° Î¼á½²Î½, his glories in the past) perish, my friends, á½Î¼Î¿á¿¦ Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´Îµ, along with (i.e., by the slaughter of) such creatures, Ï€á½³Î»Î±Ï‚, near me there.â€™ But Ï€á½³Î»Î±Ï‚ may have been a marginal gloss (on á½Î¼Î¿á¿¦), which has displaced some other word: e.g., the poet may have written Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´â€™ á½Î¼Î¿á¿¦ Î²Î¿Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ (cp. v. 453).

(4) Whatever may have been the original form of the words Îµá¼° Ï„á½° Î¼á½²Î½ Ï†Î¸á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹, Ï†á½·Î»Î¿Î¹, Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´â€™ á½Î¼Î¿á¿¦ Ï€á½³Î»Î±Ï‚, it is at least highly probable that their general sense was, â€˜If my old renown is perishing.â€™ This is suggested by the other passages where we find the same sequence of ideas,â€”i.e., the thought of his past glory closely followed by that of his present disgrace; see (1) 421â€”427: (2) 437â€”456: (3) 612â€”621.

(5) Those who believe that the antistrophic verses 423â€”427 are corrupt have a freer hand for emendation here; and, as will be seen in the Appendix, some of the proposed restorations have been very bold. But such remedies pass into the region of pure guess-work.

Line 407

Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎºÎµá½·Î¼ÎµÎ¸Î±, â€˜addictedâ€™ to them. Her. 3. 34Ï†Î¹Î»Î¿Î¹Î½á½·á¿ƒ...Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎºá½³ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹. The word can also denote, in a good sense, that to which the attention is given, as Thuc. (1. 93 Â§ 7) says of Themistocles, Ï„Î±á¿–Ï‚ Î³á½°Ï Î½Î±Ï…Ïƒá½¶ Î¼á½±Î»Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î± Ï€ÏÎ¿Ïƒá½³ÎºÎµÎ¹Ï„Î¿.

Î¼á½½ÏÎ±Î¹Ï‚. L has Î¼Ï‰ÏÎ±á¿–Ï‚ (as it has Î¼Ï‰Ïá½°Î½ in El. 890), that being the later accent, according to the general rule that adjectives in â€ÏÎ¿Ï‚ are oxytone. As I have noted in writing on the Troad elsewhere, â€˜nearly all the plains and hills are more or less well-wooded. Besides the valonia oak, the elm, willow, cypress and tamarisk shrub abound. Lotus, galingale, and reeds are still plentiful, as in Homeric days, about the streams in the Trojan plain.â€™ (Encyc. Brit., art. â€˜Troad,â€™ vol. XXIII. p. 578.)

á½¦ Î£ÎºÎ±Î¼á½±Î½Î´ÏÎ¹Î¿Î¹ ğŸ—©
Line 417

Î£ÎºÎ±Î¼á½±Î½Î´ÏÎ¹Î¿Î¹ â€¦ á¿¥Î¿Î±á½·: cp. Il. 2. 467á¼Î½ Î»ÎµÎ¹Î¼á¿¶Î½Î¹ Î£ÎºÎ±Î¼Î±Î½Î´Ïá½·á¿³ á¼€Î½Î¸ÎµÎ¼á½¹ÎµÎ½Ï„Î¹. The Scamander, still called the Mendere, is the most important river of the Troad. Rising in Ida, it flows through the central plain which now bears the name of the town Bairamitch, and thence passes northward into the plain of Troy. On the confines between the two plains, where the river winds in large curves through deep gorges in limestone rocks, its scenery is striking. From the south border of the Trojan plain to the Hellespont, the Mendere has a course of between seven and eight miles.

This vaunt of Ajax (modified only by the half-apologetic á¼”Ï€Î¿Ï‚ á¼Î¾ÎµÏá¿¶ Î¼á½³Î³Î±) is epic in tone; thus Achilles says of himself ï¼ˆIl. 18. 105), Ï„Î¿á¿–Î¿Ï‚ á¼á½¼Î½ Î¿á¼·Î¿Ï‚ Î¿á½”Ï„Î¹Ï‚ Î‘Ï‡Î±Î¹á¿¶Î½ Ï‡Î±Î»ÎºÎ¿Ï‡Î¹Ï„á½½Î½Ï‰Î½: Odysseus, ï¼ˆOd. 9. 19,) á½ƒÏ‚ Ï€á¾¶ÏƒÎ¹ Î´á½¹Î»Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼€Î½Î¸Ïá½½Ï€Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ Î¼á½³Î»Ï‰, ÎºÎ±á½· Î¼ÎµÏ… ÎºÎ»á½³Î¿Ï‚ Î¿á½ÏÎ±Î½á½¸Î½ á¼µÎºÎµÎ¹. Such a tone is better suited, indeed, to epos (in which speech is sometimes little more than audible thought) than to drama. But here, at least, as in the case of Heracles ( Tr. 1101 f.), it has the excuse of being prompted by the anguish of a sudden overthrow. (Cp. n. on O. Od. 7. 54á¼ˆÏá½µÏ„Î· Î´â€™ á½„Î½Î¿Î¼â€™ á¼ÏƒÏ„á½¶Î½ á¼Ï€á½½Î½Ï…Î¼Î¿Î½: ib. 19. 409 Ï„á¿· Î´â€™ á½ˆÎ´Ï…ÏƒÎµá½ºÏ‚ á½„Î½Î¿Î¼â€™ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Ï‰ á¼Ï€á½½Î½Ï…Î¼Î¿Î½: where in each case á¼Ï€á½½Î½Ï…Î¼Î¿Î½ means that the name is significant (the queen was the â€˜desired oneâ€™; the child was to be â€˜a man of wrathâ€™). This usage of á¼Ï€á½½Î½Ï…Î¼Î¿Ï‚, with ref. to the aptness of a name (or surname), is different from that in which a person or thing is said to be á¼Ï€á½½Î½Ï…Î¼á½¹Ï‚ Ï„Î¹Î½Î¿Ï‚, either as (1) being named from it, or (2) giving a name to it. Cp. 574.

Pindar adopts the derivation of Î‘á¼´Î±Ï‚ from Î±á¼°ÎµÏ„á½¹Ï‚: I. 5. 53 ÎºÎ±á½· Î½Î¹Î½ á½„ÏÎ½Î¹Ï‡Î¿Ï‚ Ï†Î±Î½á½³Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Îºá½³ÎºÎ»ÎµÏ„â€™ á¼Ï€á½½Î½Ï…Î¼Î¿Î½ Îµá½ÏÏ…Î²á½·Î±Î½ Î‘á¼´Î±Î½Ï„Î±. This was the popular etymology (schol. Apoll. Rh. 1. 1289; schol. Theocr. 13. 37: Apollod. 3. 12 Â§ 7). But the association of Î‘á¼´Î±Ï‚ with Î±á¼¶ Î±á¼¶ appears in the legend that a hyacinth (on whose petals the letters AI were supposed to be legible, Moschus 3. 6) sprang from the blood of Ajax, as it had sprung from that of Hyacinthus: Ov. Met. 13. 397: Littera communis mediis pueroque viroque | Inscripta est foliis; haec nominis (Ajax), illa querelae (the wail of Hyacinthus).

So Odysseus was associated with á½€Î´á½»ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹ ( Od. 1. 62Ï„á½· Î½á½» Î¿á¼± Ï„á½¹ÏƒÎ¿Î½ á½ Î´á½»ÏƒÎ±Î¿, Î–Îµá¿¦; imitated by Soph. , fr. 880): Pentheus, with Ï€á½³Î½Î¸Î¿Ï‚ ( Eur. Bacch. 507): Polyneices, with Î½Îµá¿–ÎºÎ¿Ï‚ ( Aesch. Th. 577, etc., Soph. Ant. 110 f.): Meleager, with Î¼ÎµÎ»á½³Î± á¼„Î³ÏÎ± ( Eur. fr. 517): SidÃªro with Ïƒá½·Î´Î·ÏÎ¿Ï‚ ( Soph. fr. 597): and Helen is á¼Î»á½³Î½Î±Ï…Ï‚, etc. ( Aesch. Ag. 689).

Such play on names did not seem to the Greeks unworthy of grave poetry, because to them the omens conveyed by words (á½€Î¼Ï†Î±á½·, ÎºÎ»Î·Î´á½¹Î½ÎµÏ‚) were so serious. In modern poetry, too, it has sometimes been used with tragic pathos. Thus Dante Purg. XIII. 109 Savia non fui, avvegna che SapÃ­a Fossi chiamata: and Shakesp. Rich. II. act 2 sc. 1. 73 (Gaunt) O how that name befits my composition! | Old Gaunt indeed; and gaunt in being old etc. The king asks, Can sick men play so nicely with their names? No, is the reply, misery makes sport to mock itself.

The real etymology of Î‘á¼´Î±Ï‚ is uncertain. Vase-inscriptions show that the original form was Î‘á¼´vÎ±Ï‚, and Sonne (in Kuhn's Zeitschr. 10 p. 126) compares Indog. aiva, Skr. eva (â€˜courseâ€™ï¼‰â€”a derivation which Brugmann approves (Stud. z. griech. u. lat. Gramm. 4. 180). The sense, â€˜swift runner,â€™ would suit ÎŸá¼°Î»á¿†Î¿Ï‚ Ï„Î±Ï‡á½ºÏ‚ Î‘á¼´Î±Ï‚ better than the son of Telamon: and it is not improbable (as Fleischer suggests in Roscher's Lex.p. 139) that the names of the two heroes, though identical in form, were of distinct origin.

á¼Î³á½¼ Î´â€™ á½ ÎºÎµá½·Î½Î¿Ï… Ï€Î±á¿–Ï‚, Ï„á½¸Î½ Î±á½Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼Ï‚ Ï„á½¹Ï€Î¿Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 437

Ï„á½¹Ï€Î¿Î½ Î¤ÏÎ¿á½·Î±Ï‚, i.e. Î¤ÏÎ¿á½·Î±Î½: a periphrasis like Ï„á½¸Î½ ÎšÎ¹Î¸Î±Î¹Ïá¿¶Î½Î¿Ï‚ Ï„á½¹Ï€Î¿Î½ ( O. T. 1134). Here Î¤ÏÎ¿á½·Î± is used in the Homeric manner, to denote not only the city but the country; á¼¡ Î¤Ïá¿³á½±Ï‚, as=â€˜the Troad,â€™ occurs first in Herodotus (5. 122).

á¼Ï€ÎµÎ»Î¸á½¼Î½, after Telamon; cp. á¼Ï€Î¹Î³á½·Î³Î½Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹.

Îµá¼° â€¦ ÎºÏá½·Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½ á¼”Î¼ÎµÎ»Î»Îµ, â€˜if he had been going to award,â€™ â€˜if it had devolved upon him to award.â€™ The imperfect (here referring to an unreal condition in past, not in present, time) is rightly used, because it expresses the constraint of a supposed situation. á¼€Î»Î»á½° Î´á¿†Ï„), introducing another alternative, as in El. 537(n.).

á¼”ÏÏ…Î¼Î±, their city-wall; cp. Her. 7. 223Ï„á½¸ á¼”ÏÏ…Î¼Î± Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï„Îµá½·Ï‡ÎµÎ¿Ï‚.

Î¼á½¹Î½Î¿Ï‚ Î¼á½¹Î½Î¿Î¹Ï‚: for the doubled adj., see on 267. The point of Î¼á½¹Î½Î¿Î¹Ï‚ is that the Trojans will not have their attention distracted by any other Greek foe. The phrase is thus an expression of the warrior's proud self-reliance (cp. 423 f.): it is marred by reading Ï€Î¿Î»Î»Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Î¼á½¹Î½Î¿Ï‚ (cr. n.).

Î´Ïá¿¶Î½ Ï„Î¹ Ï‡ÏÎ·ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î½: for the order of words, cp. Ar. Ach. 128á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼ÏÎ³á½±ÏƒÎ¿Î¼Î±á½· Ï„Î¹ Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á½¸Î½ á¼”ÏÎ³Î¿Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼á½³Î³Î±. The sense of Î´Ïá¾¶Î½ Ï„Î¹ alone is often similar: El. 305n. The pres. part., not Î´Ïá½±ÏƒÎ±Ï‚, because he would die in the act.â€”There was a legend, which the poet glances at here, that Ajax, in his madness, attacked the Trojans with success; manu restituit praelium insaniens ( Cic. Tusc. 4. 23); and that his death was caused by an arrow from the bow of Paris: see n. on the Argument to the play, line 33.

Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ á¼¦Î¼Î±Ï á¼¡Î¼á½³ÏÎ±, â€˜the successiveâ€™ (not, â€˜alternateâ€™) â€˜daysâ€™: the series formed by placing each new day at the side of its predecessors, as á¼€Î½á½´Ï Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ á¼„Î½Î´ÏÎ± could be said of forming men in rank. The sense is: â€˜When a man's miseries are unbroken, Ï„á½· Ï„á½³ÏÏ€ÎµÎ¹Î½ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ á¼¡Î¼á½³ÏÎ± Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ á¼¦Î¼Î±Ï, what power to please him has each successive day, Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ¸Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ± (Î±á½Ï„á½¸Î½) Ï„á¿· ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¸Î±Î½Îµá¿–Î½, when it has brought him close up to death, Îºá¼€Î½Î±Î¸Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ± Ï„Î¿á¿¦ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¸Î±Î½Îµá¿–Î½, and then again moved him back from death?â€™ Death is the boundary-line (Î³ÏÎ±Î¼Î¼á½µ) on the field of life: Eur. El. 955Ï€Ïá½¶Î½ á¼‚Î½ Ï€á½³Î»Î±Ï‚ | Î³ÏÎ±Î¼Î¼á¿†Ï‚ á¼µÎºÎ·Ï„Î±Î¹ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á½³Î»Î¿Ï‚ Îºá½±Î¼Ïˆá¿ƒ Î²á½·Î¿Ï… (mors ultima linea rerum). The man who is captive to evil fortune is like a Ï€ÎµÏƒÏƒá½¹Ï‚ on the draughtboard, at one moment moved close up to the line, and then again withdrawn from it a little; but it is death, after all,â€”death and nothing else,â€”that awaits him (Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î³Îµ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¸Î±Î½Îµá¿–Î½). This is not the platitude, â€˜all men must dieâ€™, but a thought sug gested by the case of the man â€˜whose woes are unvarying.â€™ Life has nothing in store for him; the question is merely whether he is to die at once, or to have a short and wretched reprieve. This is brought out by v. 479: ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶Ï‚ Î¶á¿†Î½ is denied to him; and that being so, the next best thing is to die honourably and quicklyâ€”ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶Ï‚ Ï„ÎµÎ¸Î½Î·Îºá½³Î½Î±Î¹.

Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ¸Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ±: cp. I. A. 540 Ï€Ïá½¶Î½ á¼Î¹Î´á¿ƒ Ï€Î±á¿–Î´â€™ á¼Î¼á½´Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ¸á¿¶ Î»Î±Î²á½½Î½: Hec. 368á¼Î¹Î´á¿ƒ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î¸Îµá¿–Ïƒâ€™ á¼Î¼á½¸Î½ Î´á½³Î¼Î±Ï‚. The dat. Ï„á¿· ÎºÎ±Ï„Î¸Î±Î½Îµá¿–Î½ is easily supplied from the genitive, which is adapted to the nearer participle.

Ï„á¿†Ï‚ á¼€Î½Î±Î³ÎºÎ±á½·Î±Ï‚ Ï„á½»Ï‡Î·Ï‚. The phrase means simply, â€˜a fortune imposed by á¼€Î½á½±Î³ÎºÎ·,â€™â€”by necessity, fate; but it has different shades of meaning according to the context. Î±á¼´Î´ÎµÏƒÎ±Î¹ â€¦ Ï€ÏÎ¿Î»Îµá½·Ï€Ï‰Î½. The participle, when used with Î±á¼°ÏƒÏ‡á½»Î½Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ or Î±á¼°Î´Î¿á¿¦Î¼Î±Î¹, implies that the person is doing, or has done, the act which causes shame. The infinitive implies that he has not yet done it. Cp. Xen. Cyr. 5. 1Â§ 21 ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿ Î¼á½²Î½ Î¿á½Îº Î±á¼°ÏƒÏ‡á½»Î½Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ Î»á½³Î³Ï‰Î½Â· Ï„á½¸ Î´â€™ â€˜á¼á½°Î½ Î¼á½³Î½Î·Ï„Îµ Ï€Î±Ïâ€™ á¼Î¼Î¿á½·, á¼€Ï€Î¿Î´á½½ÏƒÏ‰,â€™.. Î±á¼°ÏƒÏ‡Ï…Î½Î¿á½·Î¼Î·Î½ á¼‚Î½ Îµá¼°Ï€Îµá¿–Î½: (â€˜I am not ashamed of saying this; but I should be ashamed to say that.â€™) Here, Ï€ÏÎ¿Î»Îµá½·Ï€Ï‰Î½ is more forcible than an infinitive. Since his words pointed to a fixed resolve (479 f.), she speaks as if he were already engaged in the deed.

ÎºÎ»Î·ÏÎ¿á¿¦Ï‡Î¿Î½ is not elsewhere thus used, but the fact that a word had a technical (and prosaic) sense was no bar to its figurative use in Attic poetry; cp. Ï€Ïá½±ÎºÏ„Ï‰Ï and Îµá½”Î¸Ï…Î½Î¿Ï‚ ( El. 953 n.). Isocr. or. 5 Â§ 136 has the phrase Îµá½Î½Î¿á½·Î±Ï‚..ÎºÎ»Î·ÏÎ¿Î½á½¹Î¼Î¿Ï…Ï‚ (â€˜heirsâ€™).

á½‘Ï€â€™ á½€ÏÏ†Î±Î½Î¹ÏƒÏ„á¿¶Î½ (Î´Î¹Î¿á½·ÏƒÎµÏ„Î±Î¹), if he shall have his life controlled by them: cp. á½‘Ï€á½¹ with the midd. Ï€Î¿ÏÎµá½»ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ in 1253 f.: O. Î¼á½´ Ï†á½·Î»Ï‰Î½ (the generic Î¼á½µ), of no friendly kind; for the order, cp. Aesch. Eum. 903á½Ï€Î¿á¿–Î± Î½á½·ÎºÎ·Ï‚ Î¼á½´ ÎºÎ±Îºá¿†Ï‚ á¼Ï€á½·ÏƒÎºÎ¿Ï€Î±. [The Î¼á½´ could also be explained by Îµá¼° in 510: but this is less simple.]

Î²Î»á½³Ï€Ï‰, pres. subjunct.: this is the indirect form of Îµá¼°Ï‚ Ï„á½· Î²Î»á½³Ï€Ï‰; Cp. 428 á¼á¿¶ (n.).

á¾”ÏƒÏ„Ï‰ÏƒÎ±Ï‚. There is no other certain instance of á¾€ÏƒÏ„á½¹Ï‰ for á¼€ÏŠÏƒÏ„á½¹Ï‰. (In fr. 493, Îºá½¹ÏÎ¿Î½ á¼€ÏŠÏƒÏ„á½½ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ Ï€Ï…Ïá½·, Kuster's conjecture ÎºÎ·Ïá½¸Î½, if right, would point to á¾€ÏƒÏ„á½½ÏƒÎ±Ï‚.) The ordinary form occurs in Tr. 881Î±á½‘Ï„á½´Î½ Î´Î¹Î·á¿“ÏƒÏ„Ï‰ÏƒÎµ.

Î´Î¿Ïá½·. As to this form versus Î´á½¹ÏÎµÎ¹, see on O.C. 1304.

515 Ï€Î»á½´Î½ ÏƒÎ¿á¿¦. Ïƒá½º Î³á½±Ï Î¼Î¿Î¹ Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½·Î´â€™ á¾”ÏƒÏ„Ï‰ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ Î´á½¹ÏÎµÎ¹,
ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼Î·Ï„á½³Ïâ€™ á¼„Î»Î»Î· Î¼Î¿á¿–ÏÎ± Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï†á½»ÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„á½± Ï„Îµ ğŸ—©
Line 516

á¼„Î»Î»Î· Î¼Î¿á¿–ÏÎ±. Destiny, working through Ajax, ravaged her country. Destiny in some other form brought her father and mother to the grave. The poet did not wish to represent Tecmessa as living with the man who had slain her parents; and so followed, or invented, a legend which ascribed their deaths to a different agency. Throughout this speech, the Homeric scene between Hector and AndromachÃ¨ is present to the mind of Sophocles. AndromachÃ¨'s father had been slain by Achilles; her mother, by the visitation of Artemis ( Il. 6. 414â€”428).

Î¤á½³. ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼á½´Î½ Ï†á½¹Î²Î¿Î¹Ïƒá½· Î³â€™ Î±á½Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼Î¾ÎµÎ»Ï…Ïƒá½±Î¼Î·Î½. ğŸ—©
Line 531

ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼á½´Î½ Ï†á½¹Î²Î¿Î¹Ïƒá½· Î³). The formula ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼á½µÎ½ (lit. â€˜and verilyâ€™) introduces a new fact or thought; as in Tragedy it often announces a new comer (1168). When this new fact or thought raises a difficulty in the way of something proposed by the last speaker, then ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼á½µÎ½ acquires an adversative force. Thus here, its literal sense, â€˜and verily,â€™ â€˜indeed,â€™ is tinged by the context with the sense, â€˜oh, but,â€™ or â€˜nay, but.â€™ The effect of Î³Îµ is to place a slight stress on Ï†á½¹Î²Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹. The combination ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼á½µÎ½ â€¦ Î³Îµ is very frequent with Sophocles: cp. 539: O. T. 290, O. T. 345, O. T. 836, O. T. 987, O. T. 1004, O. T. 1066: O. C. 396: Ant. 221: Ph. 660: El. 1045, El. 1188.In all these passages the effect of Î³Îµ is the same; i.e., it does not modify the sense of ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¼á½µÎ½, but emphasises the word or phrase with which it is immediately connected.

Ï†á½¹Î²Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹, causal dat.: the plur. as in O. T. 585Î¾á½ºÎ½ Ï†á½¹Î²Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹. Her fears were indicated at v. 340.

á¼Î¾ÎµÎ»Ï…Ïƒá½±Î¼Î·Î½, lit. â€˜releasedâ€™: i.e., allowed him to leave the tent. The midd. á¼ÎºÎ»á½»Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ means to â€˜release,â€™ â€˜set free,â€™ in O.T. 1003, Ant. 1112, Tr. 21: H. 7. 1. 25 á¼Î¾ÎµÎ»á½»ÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„Î¿ Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ á¼ˆÏÎ³Îµá½·Î¿Ï…Ï‚. The choice of the word seems to be prompted by a wish not to say more than is implied in Ï†á½¹Î²Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹, or to imply that she had rescued the child from a danger. She speaks merely as if (in her undefined â€˜fearsâ€™) she had left the care of the child to others. Then the blunt and impatient question of Ajaxâ€”á¼Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´Îµ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ ÎºÎ±ÎºÎ¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹Î½ Îº.Ï„.Î».â€”startles her into speaking plainly,â€”Î¼á½´ ÏƒÎ¿á½· Î³á½³ Ï€Î¿Ï… Î´á½»ÏƒÏ„Î·Î½Î¿Ï‚ Îº.Ï„.Î».

The conjecture á¼Î¾ÎµÏÏÏ…Ïƒá½±Î¼Î·Î½ (cr. n.), â€˜rescued,â€™ would efface this trait of reticence. It is inferred from the scholiast's phrase, Ï„á¿¶Î½ Ï†á½¹Î²Ï‰Î½ Ï‡á½±ÏÎ¹Î½ á¿¥á½»ÏƒÎ±ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Î¸á½³Î»Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ± á¼Î¾á½µÎ³Î±Î³Î¿Î½. 554 b [Ï„á½¸ Î¼á½´ Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½Îµá¿–Î½ Î³á½°Ï Îº.Ï„.Î».] Such an unconsciousness is an â€˜evil,â€™ as excluding Ï„á½¸ Ï‡Î±á½·ÏÎµÎ¹Î½, but â€˜painless,â€™ as exempt from Ï„á½¸ Î»Ï…Ï€Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹. This verse was probably written in the margin, as a parallel passage to v. 554, and then crept into the text. It may come (as ValckenÃ¤r thought) from some other play of Sophocles; its tone seems less suggestive of Euripides. That it was a familiar quotation, may be seen from the way in which it is brought in by the novelist Eustathius (or Eumathius), in Ï„á½¸ ÎºÎ±Î¸â€™ á½™ÏƒÎ¼á½·Î½Î·Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á½™ÏƒÎ¼Î¹Î½á½·Î±Î½ ÏƒÏá¾¶Î¼Î± (c. 1100 A.D. ?), ch. 2 Â§ 7 (Erot. Scriptores vol. II. p. 174 ed. Hercher), Ï„Î¿á¿¦ á¼”Ï€Î¿Ï…Ï‚ á¼Î¼Î½á½µÏƒÎ¸Î·Î½ á½¡Ï‚ Ï„á½¸ Î¼á½´ Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½Îµá¿–Î½ Îºá½±ÏÏ„â€™ á¼€Î½á½½Î´Ï…Î½Î¿Î½ ÎºÎ±Îºá½¹Î½. It is translated, along with v. 553, in the sentences of Publilius Syrus (c. 45 B.C.), 876 f., Suavissima haec est vita, si sapias nihil: | Nam sapere nil doloris expers est malum. But those two verses are doubtless later interpolations in the text of Publilius: they are wanting in the best MS. (Monac. lat. 6292).

Î¼á½³Ï‡ÏÎ¹Ï‚ Î¿á½—. This verse is doubtless due to an interpolator who wished to limit Îµá¼°ÏƒÎ±Îµá½·. It has three marks of spuriousness. (1) Î¼á½³Ï‡ÏÎ¹, not Î¼á½³Ï‡ÏÎ¹Ï‚, is the Attic form. 575 Î•á½Ïá½»ÏƒÎ±ÎºÎµÏ‚, á¼´ÏƒÏ‡Îµ Î´Î¹á½° Ï€Î¿Î»Ï…ÏÏá½±Ï†Î¿Ï… ÏƒÏ„Ïá½³Ï†Ï‰Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 575

Ï€Î¿Î»Ï…ÏÏá½±Ï†Î¿Ï… â€¦ Ï€á½¹ÏÏ€Î±ÎºÎ¿Ï‚. This must be interpreted by the usage of the poet's day, not by Homeric practice. The Ï€á½¹ÏÏ€Î±Î¾ may be seen on shields depicted in Greek vase-paintings; an example is reproduced in Smith's Dict. of Antiquities (3rd ed., vol. I. p. 459, art. clipeus). It was a leathern thong, running round the inner edge of the shield, and fixed at intervals of six inches or so by pins or nails, so as to form a succession of loops. The name, Ï€á½¹ÏÏ€Î±Î¾, was derived from these pins (Ï€á½¹ÏÏ€Î±Î¹), which could be taken out, when it was wished to remove the Ï€á½¹ÏÏ€Î±Î¾ and so to unfit the shield for immediate use. (It is made a charge against Cleon in Ar. Eq. 849 that he had dedicated the shields taken at Pylos Î±á½Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Ï€á½¹ÏÏ€Î±Î¾Î¹Î½.)

But a loop at the edge of the shield, such as the Ï€á½¹ÏÏ€Î±Î¾ offered to the warrior's hand ( Helen. 1376 á¼Î¼Î²Î±Î»á½¼Î½ Ï€á½¹ÏÏ€Î±ÎºÎ¹ Î³ÎµÎ½Î½Î±á½·Î±Î½ Ï‡á½³ÏÎ±), would not suffice to give him control. Hence, in the vasepainting noticed above, we see the Ï€á½¹ÏÏ€Î±Î¾ combined with another contrivance, viz., a band (of metal, or wood), placed vertically across the inside of the shield, and furnished at the middle with an arrangement of small bars, forming a support for the arm just below the elbow. This band was the á½„Ï‡Î±Î½Î¿Î½ or á½€Ï‡á½±Î½Î·.â€”See Appendix.

Ï€Î¿Î»Ï…ÏÏá½±Ï†Î¿Ï… (â€˜much, or well, stitchedâ€™) is a general epithet for elaborate leatherwork, and is again illustrated by the vase-painting cited above, where ornamental tassels hang from the pins which divide the loops of the Ï€á½¹ÏÏ€Î±Î¾. In Theocr. 25. 265, Ï€Î¿Î»á½»ÏÏÎ±Ï€Ï„á½¹Î½ Ï„Îµ Ï†Î±Ïá½³Ï„ÏÎ·Î½, the epithet probably refers to braiding; quivers were often made of hide or leather.

á¼‘Ï€Ï„á½±Î²Î¿Î¹Î¿Î½=epic á¼‘Ï€Ï„Î±Î²á½¹ÎµÎ¹Î¿Î½: see n. on 19. The second part of the compound is not Î²Î¿á¿¦Ï‚, but Î²Î¿Îµá½·Î±, ox-hide ( Il. 12. 296). The shield was the work of Î¤Ï…Ï‡á½·Î¿Ï‚, ÏƒÎºÏ…Ï„Î¿Ï„á½¹Î¼Ï‰Î½ á½„Ï‡â€™ á¼„ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚,â€”so essentially was the currier's art that which it chiefly demanded ( Il. 7. 220). Tychios dwelt at á½Î»Î·,â€”probably the Boeotian ( Il. 2. 500). The number of seven layers of hide was probably exceptional; in Il. 15. 479Teucer has a Ïƒá½±ÎºÎ¿Ï‚ Ï„ÎµÏ„ÏÎ±Î¸á½³Î»Ï…Î¼Î½Î¿Î½, i.e., with four such layers.

Ï€á½¹ÏÏ€Î±ÎºÎ¿Ï‚, á¼‘Ï€Ï„á½±Î²Î¿Î¹Î¿Î½ á¼„ÏÏÎ·ÎºÏ„Î¿Î½ Ïƒá½±ÎºÎ¿Ï‚Â·
Ï„á½° Î´â€™ á¼„Î»Î»Î± Ï„Îµá½»Ï‡Î· ÎºÎ¿á½·Î½â€™ á¼Î¼Î¿á½¶ Ï„ÎµÎ¸á½±ÏˆÎµÏ„Î±Î¹. ğŸ—©
Line 577

Ï„ÎµÎ¸á½±ÏˆÎµÏ„Î±Î¹. Here, as at 1141, the fut. perf. gives a peremptory tone. Athena uses it in I. T. 1464: Î¿á½— ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„ÎµÎ¸á½±ÏˆÎµÎ¹. (Cp. Nub. 1436 Ï„ÎµÎ¸Î½á½µÎ¾ÎµÎ¹Ï‚.) The ordinary fut. pass. was Ï„Î±Ï†á½µÏƒÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹. The practice of burying a warrior's arms with him was a primitive Aryan custom; witness the swords found in the graves at Mycenae. Sophocles in this play follows the legend that the body of Ajax was interred, and not, as was the ordinary practice in the heroic age, burned (cp. 1166 n.). The reference to the burial of the arms is thus perfectly fitting. There was less meaning in the practice, noticed by Homer, of burning a warrior's armour with him; Il. 6. 418á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼„ÏÎ± Î¼Î¹Î½ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½³ÎºÎ·Îµ Ïƒá½ºÎ½ á¼”Î½Ï„ÎµÏƒÎ¹ Î´Î±Î¹Î´Î±Î»á½³Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹Î½: Od. 11. 74á¼€Î»Î»á½± Î¼Îµ ÎºÎ±ÎºÎºá¿†Î±Î¹ Ïƒá½ºÎ½ Ï„Îµá½»Ï‡ÎµÏƒÎ¹Î½. It may have come down from the earlier days when interment was the rule. No arms are burned on the pyre of Patroclus ( Il. 23. 165 ff.), Hector (24. 785 ff.), or Achilles ( Od. 24. 65 ff.).

Line 595

á¼„ÏÏ„Î¹: i.e. this new hope (if such she has) is one of which long experience might have taught her the vanity.

Ajax is now withdrawn into the tent on the eccyclema (Îµá¼°ÏƒÎºÏ…ÎºÎ»Îµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹), and the entrance is closed. Tecmessa and her child retire by another door into the part of the dwelling which is supposed to represent the Î³Ï…Î½Î±Î¹Îºá½½Î½. They re-enter after the Choral ode, and are present while Ajax speaks (see 684 ff.). Some, indeed, suppose that they remain on the scene during the ode; but the command of Ajax to Tecmessa in 579 f., Î¼Î·Î´â€™ á¼Ï€Î¹ÏƒÎºá½µÎ½Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Î³á½¹Î¿Ï…Ï‚ | Î´á½±ÎºÏÏ…Îµ, is against this.

Welcker thinks that not only Tecmessa (with the child), but Ajax also, remain present during the ode. (Rhein. Mus. for 1829, part 3, p. 87.) It is clear, however, from v. 593 that Ajax withdraws into the tent.

Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½á¿³, notwithstanding Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Ï‚ in 600. Tennyson's poem, The LotosEaters, begins thus:â€”â€˜â€œCourage!â€ he said, and pointed toward the land, | â€œThis mounting wave will roll us shoreward soon.â€ | In the afternoon they came unto a land | In which it seemed always afternoon.â€™ The repetition of the word â€˜landâ€™ there was deliberate, being designed to suggest languor. Sophocles doubtless had no such conscious aim here; he was simply indifferent, as so often, to the recurrence ( O. C. 554 n.); but something of a like effect is actually produced. The conjecture Ï€á½¹Î½á¿³ for Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½á¿³ is not probable.

Line 622

Ïƒá½»Î½Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï†Î¿Ï‚ is strongly recommended by metrical reasons, for the short Î¼á½³Î½ (=the 1st syll. of ÎºÎµá½»Î¸Ï‰Î½ in 635) is very difficult to defend. Ï€Î±Î»Î±Î¹á¾· â€¦ á¼Î¼á½³Ïá¾³, the day of old age; cp. Eur. Ion 720Î½á½³Î±Î½ Î´â€™ á¼Î¼á½³ÏÎ±Î½ á¼€Ï€Î¿Î»Î¹Ï€á½¼Î½ Î¸á½±Î½Î¿Î¹. Ar. Ran. 347Ï‡ÏÎ¿Î½á½·Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Ï„â€™ á¼Ï„á¿¶Î½ Ï€Î±Î»Î±Î¹á¿¶Î½ á¼Î½Î¹Î±Ï…Ï„Î¿á½»Ï‚.

Î»ÎµÏ…Îºá¿·, the general epithet of Î³á¿†ÏÎ±Ï‚, seems slightly more poetical here than Î»ÎµÏ…Îºá½°, though the latter may be supported by Eur. H. F. 909á½¦ Î»ÎµÏ…Îºá½° Î³á½µÏá¾³ Ïƒá½½Î¼Î±Ï„). Cp. Eur. Bacch. 258Î³á¿†ÏÎ±Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Î»Î¹á½¹Î½. á¼Îº Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá¿´Î±Ï‚ á¼¥ÎºÏ‰Î½ Î³ÎµÎ½Îµá¾¶Ï‚ á¼„ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚ â€¦ á¼ˆÏ‡Î±Î¹á¿¶Î½, lit., â€˜noblest of the Achaeans by his descent (á¼¥ÎºÏ‰Î½) from the line of his fathersâ€™: i.e., having a prouder lineage than any other Achaean can claim. á¼¥ÎºÏ‰Î½ here, going with á¼„ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚, has nearly the same force as (e.g.) in O. Paehler, in an essay on ancient steel (1885), and by Prof. H. BlÃ¼mner in his work on Greek and Roman technology (1887): see Appendix.

á¼Î¸Î·Î»á½»Î½Î¸Î·Î½ ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î±. The aor. is like á¼Ï€á¿„Î½ÎµÏƒÎ± in 536 (n.): i.e., it refers, like Î¿á¼°ÎºÏ„á½·ÏÏ‰, to the present, not to the time at which Tecmessa spoke. (Verses 594 f. suffice to prove this.) ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î±, standing so close to Î²Î±Ï†á¿‡ Ïƒá½·Î´Î·ÏÎ¿Ï‚ á½¥Ï‚, necessarily suggests the sense of a sharp, hard edge. At the same time, it refers, in its literal sense, to the Î³Î»á¿¶ÏƒÏƒÎ± Ï„ÎµÎ¸Î·Î³Î¼á½³Î½Î· (584) by which his purpose was announced. Just so the father in Aristophanes (Nub. 1107), who wishes his son to be made both acute and fluent, says, Î¼á½³Î¼Î½Î·Ïƒâ€™ á½…Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ | Îµá½– Î¼Î¿Î¹ ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î¼á½½ÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Î±á½Ï„á½¹Î½. Hence ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î± cannot be completely translated; and it is the literal sense which should here be sacrificed to the other. For the verb, cp. Anth. 5. 251. 6 Î¿á½”Ï€Ï‰ á¼Î¸Î·Î»á½»Î½Î¸Î·Ï‚ (â€˜softenedâ€™), Î¿á½Î´á½² Î¼Î±ÏÎ±Î¹Î½Î¿Î¼á½³Î½Î·.

Î²Î±Ï†á¿‡ Ïƒá½·Î´Î·ÏÎ¿Ï‚ á½£Ï‚ á¼Î¸Î·Î»á½»Î½Î¸Î·Î½ ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î±
Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á¿†ÏƒÎ´Îµ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î³Ï…Î½Î±Î¹Îºá½¹Ï‚Â· Î¿á¼°ÎºÏ„á½·ÏÏ‰ Î´á½³ Î½Î¹Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 652

Î¿á¼°ÎºÏ„á½·ÏÏ‰ â€¦ Î»Î¹Ï€Îµá¿–Î½ naturally suggests the meaning, â€˜pity forbids me to leave herâ€™; cp. á¼€Î»Î»â€™ Î±á½Ï„á½¸ Îº.Ï„.Î». So Clytaemnestra's gifts to Agamemnon's tomb are to be laid up for her with the gods below: ÎºÎµÎ¹Î¼á½µÎ»á¼° Î±á½Ï„á¿‡ Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„Î± Ïƒá¿³Î¶á½³ÏƒÎ¸Ï‰ Îºá½±Ï„Ï‰ ( El. 438). An ingenious critic, GeelJ. , writing on vv. 646â€”692 in Mnemosyne (II. pp. 200â€”208, 1853), wishes to omit this verse, because it implies the only direct falsehood in the speech; Ajax was not going to bury his sword under ground. But why should not Ajax think of the sword as destined to be buried in his grave? Ï„á½° Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á½°, the dread elemental forces of nature. The word Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á½¹Ï‚ might be called the key-note of the earlier part of this speech (cp. 648 f., 674): it comes readily to the mind of the strong man, full of the thought how strength can become weakness.

á¼ÎºÎ¿á½·Î¼Î¹ÏƒÎµ, gnomic aor., followed by the pres. Î»á½»ÎµÎ¹: cp. El. 26Î¸Ï…Î¼á½¸Î½ Î¿á½Îº á¼€Ï€á½½Î»ÎµÏƒÎµÎ½, | á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á½€ÏÎ¸á½¸Î½ Î¿á½–Ï‚ á¼µÏƒÏ„Î·ÏƒÎ¹Î½. That power can either vex the sea, or give it rest; as Aeolus, the Ï„Î±Î¼á½·Î·Ï‚ á¼€Î½á½³Î¼Ï‰Î½, has the prerogative, á¼ Î¼á½²Î½ Ï€Î±Ï…á½³Î¼ÎµÎ½Î±Î¹ á¼ Î´â€™ á½€ÏÎ½á½»Î¼ÎµÎ½, á½…Î½ Îºâ€™ á¼Î¸á½³Î»á¿ƒÏƒÎ¹ ( Od. 10. 22). So in 706 á¼ŒÏÎ·Ï‚ is a giver of peace. Cp. C. 1. 3. 15 (Notus), quo non arbiter Hadriae | Maior, tollere seu ponere vult freta. Vergil may have had Sophocles in mind when he wrote placataque venti | Dant maria ( Aen. 3. 69): but when he says, placidi straverunt aequora venti ( Aen. 5. 763), the epithet makes all the difference (=á¼„Î½ÎµÎ¼Î¿Î¹ Î»á½µÎ¾Î±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚).

Lobeck, though he refrains from changing Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á¿¶Î½ to Î»Îµá½·Ï‰Î½, thinks that the vulgate can be defended only by supposing that the foregoing verbs, á½‘Ï€Îµá½·ÎºÎµÎ¹, á¼ÎºÏ‡Ï‰ÏÎ¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ¹Î½, á¼Î¾á½·ÏƒÏ„Î±Ï„Î±Î¹, tinge á¼ÎºÎ¿á½·Î¼Î¹ÏƒÎµ with the sense, â€˜cease from troubling the seaâ€™: otherwise some addition to á¼„Î·Î¼Î±, such as Î»á¿†Î¾Î±Î½, would be needed; cp. Pind. I. 7. 12Î´Îµá¿–Î¼Î±..Ï€Î±ÏÎ¿Î¹Ï‡á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½ | ÎºÎ±ÏÏ„ÎµÏá½°Î½ á¼”Ï€Î±Ï…ÏƒÎµ Î¼á½³ÏÎ¹Î¼Î½Î±Î½. But this difficulty vanishes if á¼„Î·Î¼Î± is a personified agency.

á¼Î½ Î´), â€˜and among themâ€™; i.e., like the other powers of nature (669). á¼Î½ Î´á½³ is similarly used in O. T. 27, O. T. 181, Tr. 206.

675 ÏƒÏ„á½³Î½Î¿Î½Ï„Î± Ï€á½¹Î½Ï„Î¿Î½Â· á¼Î½ Î´â€™ á½ Ï€Î±Î³ÎºÏÎ±Ï„á½´Ï‚ á½•Ï€Î½Î¿Ï‚

á½… Ï„â€™ á¼Ï‡Î¸Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼¡Î¼á¿–Î½ Îº.Ï„.Î». The maxim is two-edged. Î¼ÎµÏ„Î±Î½ÎµÎ³Î½á½½ÏƒÎ¸Î· is prob. passive; â€˜has been converted from his anger.â€™ I cannot find an example of á¼Î³Î½á½½ÏƒÎ¸Î·Î½ (simple or compound) in any but a pass. sense. á¼€Î½ÎµÎ³Î½á½½ÏƒÎ¸Î·Î½ is regularly pass. in Herod. ; e.g. 4. 154 á¼€Î½Î±Î³Î½Ï‰ÏƒÎ¸Îµá½¶Ï‚ á½‘Ï€á½¸ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î³Ï…Î½Î±Î¹Îºá½¹Ï‚ (cp. 6. 50; 7. 7, etc.). ÎœÏ…Ïƒá½·Ï‰Î½ â€¦ ÎºÏÎ·Î¼Î½á¿¶Î½. The eastern boundary of the ancient Mysia, dividing it from Bithynia and Phrygia, is formed by the range of Olympus, which attains a height of about 8500 ft. 750 Calchas is present at this council, as he is at that in the first book of the Iliad ( Il. 1. 69). He knew by inspiration that, if Ajax could be kept in his tent for that one day, all would be well. Leaving the circle of the chiefs, he went to Teucer, who was awaiting the result in the neighbourhood. They sat down apart (cp. 780). The messenger was near them, and heard what Calchas said to Teucer.

Îµá¼¶ÏÎ¾Î±Î¹. The primitive sense of the root (vÎµÏÎ³) was to â€˜pressâ€™: whence come both the meanings of this verb, â€˜to shut out,â€™ and â€˜to shut in.â€™ Acc. to Eustathius (p. 1387. 3) the Attic form was Îµá¼´ÏÎ³Ï‰ as=ÎºÏ‰Î»á½»Ï‰ (â€˜shut outâ€™ or â€˜hinderâ€™), but Îµá¼µÏÎ³Ï‰ as=á¼Î³ÎºÎ»Îµá½·Ï‰. Curtius (Etym. Â§ 142) thinks that this distinction was of comparatively late origin. Our MSS. consistently give Îµá¼±ÏÎºÏ„á½µ, Îµá¼±ÏÎ³Î¼á½¹Ï‚, â€˜a prison.â€™ Andoc. or. 4 Â§ 27 has Îµá¼±ÏÎ³Î½á½»Ï‰Î½ (â€˜imprisoningâ€™): Plat. Tim.p. 45 E ÎºÎ±Î¸Îµá½·ÏÎ³Î½Ï…ÏƒÎ¹ (indeed, the forms from ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ³Î½Ï… are always aspirated). But in regard to the other forms the evidence of MSS. is often conflicting, and the practice of editors has varied. In Thuc. , Bekker always writers Îµá¼µÏÎ³Ï‰: Classen and Stahl, always Îµá¼´ÏÎ³Ï‰, even (e.g.) in 8. 74 Â§ 3 Îµá¼´ÏÎ¾ÎµÎ¹Î½ and 4. 47 Â§ 3 ÎºÎ±Ï„Îµá¿–ÏÎ¾Î±Î½, where the ref. is to imprisonment; though in the latter place the MSS. seem to agree on ÎºÎ±Î¸Îµá¿–ÏÎ¾Î±Î½. On the other hand in Eur. Bacch. 443 the best editions give Îµá¼¶ÏÎ¾Î±Î¹. Eur. Itmay be noted that Lobeck could find no instance of á¼€Ï†Îµá½·ÏÎ³ÎµÎ¹Î½ earlier than Aelian (Hist. An. 12. 21 á¼€Ï†ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ³Î¼á½³Î½Î·): as to á¼„Ï†ÎµÏÎºÏ„Î¿Ï‚ in Aesch. Ch. 446, he justifies it as meaning, â€˜shut in (apart),â€™ not â€˜shut off.â€™ Recent editors are generally agreed in writing Îµá¼¶ÏÎ¾Î±Î¹ here, and Îµá¼´ÏÎ³ÎµÎ¹Î½ in 795. á¼¦Î¼Î±Ï Ï„Î¿á½Î¼Ï†Î±Î½á½²Ï‚ Ï„á½¸ Î½á¿¦Î½ Ï„á½¹Î´Îµ: the cumulative phrase marks the seer's anxiety to impress the fact upon his hearer; it is like the precise fulness of 741 f., á¼”Î½Î´Î¿Î¸ÎµÎ½ ÏƒÏ„á½³Î³Î·Ï‚ | Î¼á½´ )Î¾Ï‰ Ï€Î±Ïá½µÎºÎµÎ¹Î½.

Ï„á¿‡Î´Îµ Î¸á¼¡Î¼á½³Ïá¾³. The fact that Aristophanes uses this crasis ( Av. 1071, Thesm. 76) proves that it was familiar to Athenian ears. There is no good reason for excluding it from Tragedy, when Î¿á¼´Î¼) is allowed in tragic verse on the ground that Comedy proves it to have been common.

Ï„á½° Î³á½°Ï Ï€ÎµÏÎ¹ÏƒÏƒá½° Îº.Ï„.Î». To judge the text aright here, we must remember that these are the words of the Î¼á½±Î½Ï„Î¹Ï‚, who speaks as the prophet of the gods. Ï€ÎµÏÎ¹ÏƒÏƒá½° ÎºÎ±Î½á½¹Î½Î·Ï„Î± Ï‚<*>Î¼Î±Ï„Î± are mortals whose over-great strength and success have made them wax too proud, so that they no longer serve the gods with due piety. Such mortals are á¼€Î½á½¹Î½Î·Ï„Î¿Î¹,â€”their lives can yield no worthy fruit. Compare the words of warning addressed to Xerxes ( Her. 7. 10): á½Ïá¾·Ï‚ Ï„á½° á½‘Ï€ÎµÏá½³Ï‡Î¿Î½Ï„Î± Î¶á¿·Î± á½¡Ï‚ ÎºÎµÏÎ±Ï…Î½Î¿á¿– á½ Î¸Îµá½¸Ï‚ Î¿á½Î´á½² á¼á¾· Ï†Î±Î½Ï„á½±Î¶ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹..Ï†Î¹Î»á½³ÎµÎ¹ Î³á½°Ï á½ Î¸Îµá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á½° á½‘Ï€ÎµÏá½³Ï‡Î¿Î½Ï„Î± Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î± ÎºÎ¿Î»Î¿á½»ÎµÎ¹Î½. It is not without reason, then, that the reading Îºá¼€Î½á½¹Î½Î·Ï„Î± is supported by the general consensus of ancient testimony. Îºá¼€Î½á½¹Î·Ï„Î± is adopted by several recent editors, because the folly of Ajax is elsewhere recognised (763 á¼„Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚, 766 á¼€Ï†Ïá½¹Î½Ï‰Ï‚), whereas he could not, they think, be called á¼€Î½á½¹Î½Î·Ï„Î¿Ï‚. Other explanations are the following. (1) The poet meant to add something to the effect of á¼ Ï„á½·Î¼Î±ÏƒÎµ Ï„á½´Î½ Ï€Î±ÏÎ±á½·Î½ÎµÏƒÎ¹Î½, but changed the form of the sentence. The most attractive remedy is Mehlhorn's, Î´á½·Î±Î½ á¼ˆÎ¸á½±Î½Î±Î½, so that the verb shall have the same constr. as in Ph. 1065.But, if this be right, how did the genitive arise? á½ Î´â€™ â€¦ Î¤Îµá¿¦ÎºÏÎ¿Ï‚: cp. Ph. 371á½ Î´â€™ Îµá¼¶Ï€â€™ á½ˆÎ´Ï…ÏƒÏƒÎµá½»Ï‚ (n.).

Îµá½Î¸á½ºÏ‚ á¼Î¾ á¼•Î´ÏÎ±Ï‚, immediately on rising from his seat beside Calchas (750 n.). No sooner had Calchas finished, than Teucer rose, and sent the messenger, who was close by,â€”sitting among the Î»Î±Î¿á½·. (Cp. Il. 2. 96Î»Î±á¿¶Î½ á¼±Î¶á½¹Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½,â€”in the agora.) Some take Îµá½Î¸á½ºÏ‚ á¼Î¾ á¼•Î´ÏÎ±Ï‚ as= â€˜immediately, from his seat,â€™â€”i.e., without rising (so that he would beckon or call the man to him): cp. Il. 19. 77Î±á½Ï„á½¹Î¸ÎµÎ½ á¼Î¾ á¼•Î´ÏÎ·Ï‚, Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼Î½ Î¼á½³ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼€Î½Î±ÏƒÏ„á½±Ï‚: Od. 13. 56ï¼ˆá¼”ÏƒÏ€ÎµÎ¹ÏƒÎ±Î½) Î±á½Ï„á½¹Î¸ÎµÎ½ á¼Î¾ á¼‘Î´Ïá½³Ï‰Î½, â€˜even there as they sat.â€™ But in those phrases Î±á½Ï„á½¹Î¸ÎµÎ½ helps to fix the sense: whereas á¼Îº following Îµá½Î¸á½ºÏ‚ regularly denotes the point from which the further action sets out (Îµá½Î¸á½ºÏ‚ á¼Î¾ á¼€ÏÏ‡á¿†Ï‚, Îµá½Î¸á½ºÏ‚ á¼Îº Î½á½³Î¿Ï…, etc.). Hence Îµá½Î¸á½ºÏ‚ á¼Î¾ á¼•Î´ÏÎ±Ï‚ ought to mean, â€˜immediately after sitting.â€™â€” Other explanations of á¼Î¾ á¼•Î´ÏÎ±Ï‚ are: (1) â€˜from where I (the messenger) sat.â€™ (2) â€˜After the sitting of the council.â€™ But Teucer would not wait for that. (3) â€˜Leaving the councilâ€™ (or strictly, its neighbourhood, since Calchas had come apart from it, Od. 750). This would imply that Teucer had been included in the Î¾á½»Î½ÎµÎ´ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Îºá½»ÎºÎ»Î¿Ï‚: but the tone used towards him by MenelaÃ¼s (1120 á½ Ï„Î¿Î¾á½¹Ï„Î·Ï‚) and Agamemnon (1235 Î´Î¿á½»Î»Ï‰Î½) makes this very unlikely.

Teucer sends a messenger, instead of going himself, probably because he hopes that his mediation with the chiefs may do some good. What he dreads is simply that Ajax should leave the tent; and a message could prevent that. He has no cause to suspect that Ajax meditates suicide.

Paley's conjecture, á¼Î»Ï€á½·Î¶Ï‰ Ï†á½³ÏÎµÎ¹Î½, meets the point as to Ï†á½³ÏÎµÎ¹Î½, but the change to the first person is too harsh. Could á½€Î»ÎµÎ¸Ïá½·Î±Î½ Î‘á¼´Î±Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ have come from Î‘á¼´Î±Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Îµá¼°Ï‚ á½„Î»ÎµÎ¸ÏÎ¿Î½? Easily, doubtless, if Îµá¼°Ï‚ had been lost after â€Î¿Ï‚. I incline to this solution. Î‘á¼´Î±Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Îµá¼°Ï‚ á½„Î»ÎµÎ¸ÏÎ¿Î½ is not only intrinsically better, but also slightly more probable, than á½„Î»ÎµÎ¸ÏÎ¿Î½ Îµá¼°Ï‚ Î‘á¼´Î±Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ (the reading of Blaydes in his text), since then Îµá¼°Ï‚ follows â€Î¿Î½, and its unusual position would also tend to prevent its being overlooked. Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î˜ÎµÏƒÏ„Î¿ÏÎµá½·Î¿Ï… Î¼á½±Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‰Ï‚: Il. 1. 69Îšá½±Î»Ï‡Î±Ï‚ Î˜ÎµÏƒÏ„Î¿Ïá½·Î´Î·Ï‚, Î¿á¼°Ï‰Î½Î¿Ï€á½¹Î»Ï‰Î½ á½„Ï‡) á¼„ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚. Cp. above, Il. 134, Î¤ÎµÎ»Î±Î¼á½½Î½Î¹Îµ Ï€Î±á¿–: and n. on O. T. 267.According to one legend, Thestor was the son of Idmon (á¼´Î´Î¼Ï‰Î½), the seer who accompanied the Argonauts, and whose father was Apollo (schol. Apoll. Rhod. 1. 139). The name Î˜á½³Ï‚â€Ï„Ï‰Ï is from the root Î¸ÎµÏ‚, â€˜desire,â€™ â€˜pray,â€™ whence Î¸ÎµÏƒÏƒá½±Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ (=Î±á¼°Ï„Î·Ïƒá½±Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚, Archil. fr. 11, etc.), Ï€Î¿Î»á½»Î¸ÎµÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚ â€˜much besoughtâ€™ (Curt. á½…Ï„â€™ Î±á½Ï„á¿· â€¦ Ï†á½³ÏÎµÎ¹. The traditional á½…Ï„) (á½…Ï„Îµ) seems right. Tecmessa has already heard that the á¼”Î¾Î¿Î´Î¿Ï‚ is perilous. The new fact which she is now to learn is that â€˜this dayâ€™ must decide the fate of Ajax. If, however, á½…Ï„) be changed to á½ƒÏ‚, then this new fact will not be told, unless the words ÎºÎ±Î¸â€™ á¼¡Î¼á½³ÏÎ±Î½ Ï„á½´Î½ Î½á¿¦Î½ be taken with what follows (á½ƒÏ‚..Ï†á½³ÏÎµÎ¹). If Ï†á½³ÏÎµÎ¹ be sound, the subject to it is á¼¡ á¼”Î¾Î¿Î´Î¿Ï‚ (798). There is nothing harsh in this, since the á¼”Î¾Î¿Î´Î¿Ï‚ is the matter uppermost in the minds of the speakers. Ï†á½³ÏÎµÎ¹ â€¦ Î¸á½±Î½Î±Ï„Î¿Î½ á¼¢ Î²á½·Î¿Î½ then means, â€˜is fraught with death or lifeâ€™: cp. Ph. 109Îµá¼° Ï„á½¸ ÏƒÏ‰Î¸á¿†Î½Î±á½· Î³Îµ Ï„á½¸ ÏˆÎµá¿¦Î´Î¿Ï‚ Ï†á½³ÏÎµÎ¹: El. 84Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„Î± Î³á½°Ï Ï†á½³ÏÎµÎ¹ | Î½á½·ÎºÎ·Î½: ib. 1042 Ï‡á¼¡ Î´á½·ÎºÎ· Î²Î»á½±Î²Î·Î½ Ï†á½³ÏÎµÎ¹. The subject to Ï†á½³ÏÎµÎ¹ is certainly not á¼¡Î¼á½³ÏÎ± á¼¡ Î½á¿¦Î½. If Calchas were subject to Ï†á½³ÏÎµÎ¹, the verb would mean á¼€Î³Î³á½³Î»Î»ÎµÎ¹: but, for this sense, the subject must be the á¼„Î³Î³ÎµÎ»Î¿Ï‚ himself, not the sender. á½…Ï€Î¿Î¹Ï€ÎµÏ á¼‚Î½ ÏƒÎ¸á½³Î½Ï‰. These words, implying that she has no strenght to go far, are significant, because she is to find the body of Ajax near the tent (891), while the Chorus have been vainly seeking him further off.

Line 811

á¼Î³ÎºÎ¿Î½á¿¶Î¼ÎµÎ½: cp. 988: Tr. 1255(n.).

Î¿á½Ï‡ á¼•Î´ÏÎ±Ï‚ á¼€ÎºÎ¼á½´: cp. El. 22á¼”ÏÎ³Ï‰Î½ á¼€ÎºÎ¼á½µ: Ph. 12á¼€ÎºÎ¼á½´ Î³á½°Ï Î¿á½ Î¼Î±ÎºÏá¿¶Î½ á¼¡Î¼á¿–Î½ Î»á½¹Î³Ï‰Î½. Verse 812 seems genuine. The fear which had haunted Tecmessa from the moment when Ajax regained his sanity (326), and which his words had lulled, has been revived by the message of Calchas. The definite expression of that fear, by ÏƒÏ€Îµá½»Î´á¿ƒ Î¸Î±Î½Îµá¿–Î½, is a fitting close to this scene, and prepares for the next.

As to the diction of the verse, three points claim notice. (1) The Î³Îµ after á¼„Î½Î´ÏÎ± emphasises, not that word, but the whole clause, á¼„Î½Î´ÏÎ± á½ƒÏ‚ ÏƒÏ€Îµá½»Î´á¿ƒ Î¸Î±Î½Îµá¿–Î½. Cp. Ant. 213 f., Ant. 648 f.: El. 1506: O. C. 1278.It contrasts á¼•Î´ÏÎ±Ï‚ with his ÏƒÏ€Î¿Ï…Î´á½µ. (2) ÏƒÏ€Îµá½»Î´á¿ƒ is the original reading to which L's points (cr. n.). It generalises the statement. (3) Î¸á½³Î»Î¿Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚, which was written by the first hand in L, is in its turn supported by ÏƒÏ€Îµá½»Î´á¿ƒ as against Î¸á½³Î»Î¿Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚: for, if the sentiment is general, it will depend on Î¿á½Ï‡ á¼•Î´ÏÎ±Ï‚ á¼€ÎºÎ¼á½µ more fitly than on Ï‡Ï‰Ïá¿¶Î¼ÎµÎ½. In this case, the acc. Î¸á½³Î»Î¿Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ depends on Î¿á½Ï‡ á¼•Î´ÏÎ±Ï‚ á¼€ÎºÎ¼á½µ as=Î¿á½Ï‡ á¼±Î´ÏÏ…Ï„á½³Î¿Î½, a constr. quite possible for poetry: cp. Ïƒá¿´Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½ Î¸á½³Î»Î¿Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ á¼„Î½Î´ÏÎ± Î³â€™ á½ƒÏ‚ ÏƒÏ€Îµá½»Î´á¿ƒ Î¸Î±Î½Îµá¿–Î½.
Î§Î¿. Ï‡Ï‰ÏÎµá¿–Î½ á¼•Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¼Î¿Ï‚, ÎºÎ¿á½ Î»á½¹Î³á¿³ Î´Îµá½·Î¾Ï‰ Î¼á½¹Î½Î¿Î½Â· ğŸ—©
Line 813

á¼•Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¼Î¿Ï‚, without the verb Îµá¼°Î¼á½·, as in O. T. 92: Eur. El. 796: Dem. or. 9 Â§ 4: Polit. 277 E, and often.â€” á¼”ÏÎ³Î¿Ï…, the usual antithesis to Î»á½¹Î³á¿³, is defined by Ï€Î¿Î´á¿¶Î½.

Tecmessa now leaves the scene by the entrance on the spectator's left, leading to the open country. The Messenger, with the servants of Ajax, goes out on the spectator's right, as being bound for the Greek camp.

The Chorus leave the orchestra in two á¼¡Î¼Î¹Ï‡á½¹ÏÎ¹Î±, one by the Ï€á½±ÏÎ¿Î´Î¿Ï‚ on the right, the other by that on the left. The withdrawal of the Chorus from the orchestra during the course of a play was called Î¼ÎµÏ„á½±ÏƒÏ„Î±ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚: their return, á¼Ï€Î¹Ï€á½±ÏÎ¿Î´Î¿Ï‚. The other extant examples are:â€”(1) Aesch. Eum.: Î¼ÎµÏ„á½±ÏƒÏ„Î±ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚ at v. 231: á¼Ï€Î¹Ï€á½±ÏÎ¿Î´Î¿Ï‚ at v. 299. (2) Eur. Alc.: Î¼., Eur. Alc. 746: á¼., Eur. Alc. 872.(3) Helen.: Î¼., 385: á¼., 515. (4) Ar. Eccl.: Î¼., Ar. Eccl. 310: á¼., Ar. Eccl. 478.

A change of scene is now supposed to take place, from the ground in front of the tent of Ajax to a lonely spot on the sea-shore, with trees or bushes (Î½á½±Ï€Î¿Ï‚, 892). We do not know how this change was managed. (1) It may have been indicated merely by removing the hangings on the back-wall which represented the ÏƒÎºÎ·Î½á½µ of Ajax. This is MA. Ã¼ller's view (Gr. BÃ¼hnenalterthÃ¼mer, p. 162). (2) Wecklein supposes that a back-wall, representing the ÏƒÎºÎ·Î½á½µ, was drawn back on right and left, disclosing the new scene.â€”We cannot assume the use of Ï€ÎµÏá½·Î±ÎºÏ„Î¿Î¹ in the poet's time (cp. note at the beginning of the play). Had they been in use, the Ï€ÎµÏá½·Î±ÎºÏ„Î¿Ï‚ on the spectator's left could have turned, so as to represent a new locality (Ï„á½¹Ï€Î¿Ï‚). The right-hand Ï€ÎµÏá½·Î±ÎºÏ„Î¿Ï‚, indicating the region in which the whole action takes place (Ï‡á½½ÏÎ±), would not have been changed.

The only other Greek play in which a change of scene is certain is the Eumenides, where the action begins at the temple of the Delphian Apollo, and passes at v. 235 to that of Athena Polias at Athens. This may have been marked merely by substituting a statue of Athena for one of Apollo.

815 Ajax is standing at the side of the scene on the spectator's right, near the underwood which screens him when he fallsâ€”so that his body is not at first visible to the Chorus when they return to the orchestra, but could be seen by Tecmessa, when she comes on the scene from the left. The point of the sword could probably be seen by the audience. Hesychius quotes Polemon, the sophist in Hadrian's age, as saying that the ÏƒÏ…ÏƒÏ€Î±ÏƒÏ„á½¸Î½ was used á¼Î½ Î‘á¼´Î±Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á½‘Ï€Î¿ÎºÏá½·ÏƒÎµÎ¹. It was a short stage-sword, of which the blade ran back; otherwise called á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½¹Î¼Î·Ï„Î¿Î½ (Hesych., which some refer to á¼€Î½Î±Î´ÏÎ±Î¼Îµá¿–Î½), or á¼€Î½Î´ÏÎ¿Î¼Î·Ïá½¹Î½. Cp. Achilles Tatius 3. 20 á½ Ïƒá½·Î´Î·ÏÎ¿Ï‚ Îµá¼´ÏƒÏ‰ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Î´á½»ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹, Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„á¿³ Î´)...á¼Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Î¸Îµá½±Ï„ÏÎ¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼Ï‡Ïá¿†Ï„Î¿ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á½°Ï‚ ÎºÎ¹Î²Î´á½µÎ»Î¿Ï…Ï‚ ÏƒÏ†Î±Î³á½±Ï‚.

The antithesis to á½ Î¼á½²Î½ ÏƒÏ†Î±Î³Îµá½ºÏ‚ Îº.Ï„.Î». is delayed: it is given by á¼Îº Î´á½² Ï„á¿¶Î½Î´Îµ in 823. Meanwhile, the reasons why the weapon should prove deadly have been developed in three clauses (Î´á¿¶ÏÎ¿Î½ Î¼á½²Î½â€” Ï€á½³Ï€Î·Î³Îµ Î´)â€”á¼”Ï€Î·Î¾Î± Î´)). ÏƒÏ†Î±Î³Îµá½ºÏ‚ here is simply â€˜the slayer.â€™ In Eur. Andr. 1134ÏƒÏ†Î±Î³á¿†Ï‚ are sacrificial knives.

á¼•Î»Ï‰Ï, an epic word, once used (in the plur.) by Aesch. , Suppl. 800 ÎºÏ…Ïƒá½¶Î½ Î´â€™ á¼”Ï€ÎµÎ¹Î¸â€™ á¼•Î»Ï‰ÏÎ± Îºá¼€Ï€Î¹Ï‡Ï‰Ïá½·Î¿Î¹Ï‚ | á½„ÏÎ½Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ Î´Îµá¿–Ï€Î½Î¿Î½ Î¿á½Îº á¼€Î½Î±á½·Î½Î¿Î¼Î±á½¶ Ï€á½³Î»ÎµÎ¹Î½. Ajax forebodes that, as a public enemy, he will suffer the doom which Achilles assigns to Hector ( Il. 22. 354), Creon to Polyneices ( Ant. 205), and Electra to Aegisthus ( El. 1487). The Atreidae, in fact, so intended (1064 f.).

Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼ˆÏ„ÏÎµÎ¹Î´á¿¶Î½ á½¡Ï‚ Î´Î¹á½¹Î»Î»Ï…Î¼Î±Î¹ Ï„á½±Î»Î±Ï‚,

840 Î¾Ï…Î½Î±ÏÏ€á½±ÏƒÎµÎ¹Î±Î½, á½¥ÏƒÏ€ÎµÏ Îµá¼°ÏƒÎ¿Ïá¿¶Ïƒâ€™ á¼Î¼á½²
[Î±á½Ï„Î¿ÏƒÏ†Î±Î³á¿† Ï€á½·Ï€Ï„Î¿Î½Ï„Î±, Ï„á½¼Ï‚ Î±á½Ï„Î¿ÏƒÏ†Î±Î³Îµá¿–Ï‚
Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á¿¶Î½ Ï†Î¹Î»á½·ÏƒÏ„Ï‰Î½ á¼ÎºÎ³á½¹Î½Ï‰Î½ á½€Î»Î¿á½·Î±Ï„Î¿.] ğŸ—©
Line 842

Îºá½±ÎºÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€Î±Î½Ï‰Î»á½³Î¸ÏÎ¿Ï…Ï‚: Aesch. Th. 552Ï€Î±Î½á½½Î»ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Ï€Î±Î³Îºá½±ÎºÏ‰Ï‚ Ï„â€™ á½€Î»Î¿á½·Î±Ï„Î¿.

The last two of these four verses are certainly spurious, as three things show.

(1) The poet would not have made the dying Ajax pray that the Atreidae may die â€˜at the hands of their offspring,â€™ unless there had been some legend that they so died. But, according to the current mythology, Agamemnon was slain by his wife and her paramour, while MenelaÃ¼s and Helen passed, without dying, to Elysium ( Od. 4. 561). It is only in later times that we meet with the story of MenelaÃ¼s and Helen having been sacrificed by Iphigeneia in the land of the Tauri (Ptolemy Heph. 4, cp. Roscher, Lex. p. 1951): a myth which the author of these verses may have had in view. Odysseus, indeed, was slain by Telegonus; but he does not come into account here, unless we make the improbable change of á¼ˆÏ„ÏÎµÎ¹Î´á¿¶Î½ to á¼ˆÏ‡Î±Î¹á¿¶Î½ in 838. [As to the double sense of Î±á½Ï„Î¿ÏƒÏ†Î±Î³á½µÏ‚, with ref. to one who is slain (1) by himself, (2) by a kinsman, see on Ant. 56Î±á½Ï„Î¿ÎºÏ„Î¿Î½Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Îµ.]

(2) These two verses confuse the construction, since á½¥ÏƒÏ€ÎµÏ Îµá¼°ÏƒÎ¿Ïá¿¶Ïƒâ€™ á¼Î¼á½³ (sc. Î¾Ï…Î½Î±ÏÏ€Î±ÏƒÎ¸á½³Î½Ï„Î±) refers to what precedes: while Ï„á½¼Ï‚ in 841 refers to á½¥ÏƒÏ€ÎµÏ.

(3) The form Ï†á½·Î»Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚ occurs nowhere else, except as a proper name.

Ï„á½½Ï‚ is not elsewhere found in Soph. or Eur. : it is, however, used by Aesch. , not only in lyrics ( Aesch. Th. 484, Suppl. 69, 670, 691), but once, at least, in a trimeter, Th. 637á¼¢ Î¶á¿¶Î½Ï„â€™ á¼€Ï„Î¹Î¼Î±ÏƒÏ„á¿†ÏÎ± Ï„á½¼Ï‚ á¼€Î½Î´ÏÎ·Î»á½±Ï„Î·Î½. We should not, then, insist on Ï„á½½Ï‚ as a mark of spuriousness: and á½€Î»Î¿á½·Î±Ï„Î¿ is, of course, free from objection ( O. T. 1274Î³Î½Ï‰ÏƒÎ¿á½·Î±Ï„Î¿ n.). But the case against 841 f. seems conclusive without them.

A more difficult question is whether vv. 839, 840 are also spurious. The schol. in L on v. 841 is as follows:â€”Ï„á½¼Ï‚ Î±á½Ï„Î¿ÏƒÏ†Î±Î³Îµá¿–Ï‚: Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„Î± Î½Î¿Î¸Îµá½»ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±á½· Ï†Î±ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á½‘Ï€Î¿Î²Î»Î·Î¸á½³Î½Ï„Î± Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ ÏƒÎ±Ï†á½µÎ½ÎµÎ¹Î±Î½ Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î»ÎµÎ³Î¿Î¼á½³Î½Ï‰Î½. As the lemma, Ï„á½¼Ï‚ Î±á½Ï„Î¿ÏƒÏ†Î±Î³Îµá¿–Ï‚, clearly indicates, Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„Î± refers only to the two verses 841 f., and not (as Dindorf and others have assumed) to all the four verses 839â€”842. The surmise was, says the scholiast, that vv. 841 f. were added â€˜to make the meaning clearerâ€™; i.e., to explain the elliptical phrase, á½¥ÏƒÏ€ÎµÏ Îµá¼°ÏƒÎ¿Ïá¿¶Ïƒâ€™ á¼Î¼á½³. Such a surmise itself shows that vv. 839, 840 were believed to be older than 841 f. It is indeed plain that all four verses are not by the same author. The incoherent construction noticed above, under (2), was possible for an interpolator whose attention was fixed on á½¥ÏƒÏ€ÎµÏ Îµá¼°ÏƒÎ¿Ïá¿¶Ïƒâ€™ á¼Î¼á½³, but hardly for one who was forging vv. 839â€”842 as a whole. If, then, all four verses are condemned, we must assume two independent interpolations.

I incline to think that the two verses 839 and 840 are genuine; because, otherwise, the imprecation on the Ï€á½±Î½Î´Î·Î¼Î¿Ï‚ ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï„á½¹Ï‚ (844) would follow too abruptly on v. 838. The prayer for the destruction of his chief foes, uttered in 839 f., leads up to the more sweeping denunciation of the Greek army.

Line 843

á¼´Ï„), in urgent entreaty: O. C. 106(n.).

Ï‡ÏÏ…Ïƒá½¹Î½Ï‰Ï„Î¿Î½ á¼¡Î½á½·Î±Î½. Cp. O. C. 693Ï‡ÏÏ…Ïƒá½±Î½Î¹Î¿Ï‚ á¼ˆÏ†ÏÎ¿Î´á½·Ï„Î± (n.). â€˜Goldenâ€™ is similarly an Homeric epithet, not only of reins, but of shoes ( Il. 24. 340Ï€á½³Î´Î¹Î»Î±..Ï‡Ïá½»ÏƒÎµÎ¹Î±), a belt ( Od. 11. 610Ï‡Ïá½»ÏƒÎµÎ¿Ï‚..Ï„ÎµÎ»Î±Î¼á½½Î½), and a girdle ( Od. 5. 231). Achilles Tatius (1. 14) refers to Ï†Î±Î»á½±ÏÎ¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼€ÏÎ³Ï…ÏÎ¿á¿–Ï‚, Ï‡ÏÏ…ÏƒÎ±á¿–Ï‚ á¼¡Î½á½·Î±Î¹Ï‚, as parts of a luxurious equipment. The epithet in Anth. Îºá¼€ÎºÎµá¿–=ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼Î½ á¼Î¹Î´Î¿Ï… ( Ant. 76, El. 356). In Hesiod Theog. 758 ff. Thanatos and Hypnos are the sons of Night, and dwell near Hades and PersephonÃ¨. A relief from Ephesus shows Thanatos, winged, and girt with his sword, in the nether world, at the moment when Hermes is about to bring Alcestis back to the sunlight. See Baumeister, DenkmÃ¤ler p. 281 (pl. 281), and ib. 1730, where C. Robert's interpretation of the subject is given.

Ï€á½¹Î½Î¿Ï‚ Ï€á½¹Î½á¿³ Ï€á½¹Î½Î¿Î½: cp. 1197, and n. on O. T. 175. Aesch. Pers. 1041Î´á½¹ÏƒÎ¹Î½ ÎºÎ±Îºá½°Î½ ÎºÎ±Îºá¿¶Î½ ÎºÎ±ÎºÎ¿á¿–Ï‚. The dialogue in 866â€”878 is conducted by the two leaders of hemichoria. When Sophocles raised the number of the tragic Chorus from twelve to fifteen, his object was to provide a coryphaeus (distinct from the ordinary choreutae), and two subordinate leaders. The technical name for these leaders of hemichoria was Ï€Î±ÏÎ±ÏƒÏ„á½±Ï„Î±Î¹, because they stood one on each side of the coryphaeus when the Chorus was drawn up in ranks (ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° Î¶Ï…Î³á½±).

Line 891

á¼°á½½ Î¼Î¿á½· Î¼Î¿Î¹. Tecmessa,â€”who is not seen till v. 894,â€”is approaching the entrance on the spectator's left, when she descries the body of Ajax lying at the other side of the scene. Line 903

á½¦ Ï„Î±Î»Î±á½·Ï†ÏÏ‰Î½ Î³á½»Î½Î±Î¹. We should expect either á½¦ Ï„Î±Î»Î±á¿–Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½ Î³á½»Î½Î±Î¹, or á½¢ Ï„Î±Î»Î±á½·Ï†ÏÏ‰Î½ Î³Ï…Î½á½µ, exclamatory, like El. 150á¼°á½¼ Ï€Î±Î½Ï„Î»á½±Î¼Ï‰Î½ ÎÎ¹á½¹Î²Î±. But the reading given above has the best MS. authority, and is tacitly accepted in several recent editions. I retain it, because the words, though addressed to Tecmessa, are in fact rather a comment upon her fate. Hence it is conceivable that the nom. of the adjective, usual in exclamations, should here be combined with a vocative of the person.

Î¤á½³. 905 á½¡Ï‚ á½§Î´Îµ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Î´â€™ á¼”Ï‡Î¿Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Î±á¼°á½±Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½ Ï€á½±ÏÎ±. ğŸ—©
Line 905

Ï„á½·Î½Î¿Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Ï„â€™ á¼†Ïâ€™ á¼”Ï€ÏÎ±Î¾Îµ Îº.Ï„.Î». The antistrophic verse is 951, á¼„Î³Î±Î½ á½‘Ï€ÎµÏÎ²ÏÎ¹Î¸á½²Ï‚ á¼„Ï‡Î¸Î¿Ï‚ á¼¤Î½Ï…ÏƒÎ±Î½. I believe that the text is sound here, and that Î³á½°Ï has dropped out before á¼„Ï‡Î¸Î¿Ï‚ in 951. The case is parallel with that of vv. 369 and 384, in the latter of which a syllable was lost. The only tolerable emendation of á¼”Ï€ÏÎ±Î¾Îµ is á¼”ÏÎ¾Îµ: and á¼”Ï€ÏÎ±Î¾Îµ is the fitter word, since, with its possible sense of â€˜contrived,â€™ it suits the hypothesis that he may have procured death from another's hand; while á¼”ÏÎ¾Îµ would, in that case, be somewhat forced. It may be added that the aorist of á¼”ÏÎ´Ï‰ is never used by Sophocles in the indicative (though he has á¼”ÏÎ¾ÎµÎ¹ÎµÎ½ Tr. 935, á¼”ÏÎ¾Î¿Î½ ib. 1201, á¼”ÏÎ¾Î±Ï‚ Ph. 117 etc.); and by Aeschylus only once, Th. 924á¼ÏÎ¾á½±Ï„Î·Î½ (lyr.): for in Ag. 1529á¼¦ÏÎ¾ÎµÎ½ is right, and á¼”ÏÎ¾ÎµÎ½ only a conjecture. Ï€ÎµÏÎ¹Ï€Ï„Ï…Ï‡Îµá¿– Ï†á½±ÏÎµÎ¹, a cloak or mantle wrapped round him: for the adj., cp. 899. The Ï†á½±ÏÎ¿Ï‚, we may suppose, has been brought by a Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÏ€Î¿Î»Î¿Ï‚ from the tent hard by. The shrouded corpse, which remains partly visible (cp. 1172), is an effigy, like that of Haemon in the Antigone (1258, cp. p. xvii. n.), and of Clytaemnestra in the Electra (1466). The actor who played Ajax has now to play Teucer.

From the primary sense of â€˜casting out,â€™ á¼ÎºÎ²á½±Î»Î»ÎµÎ¹Î½ derives that of â€˜throwing away,â€™ â€˜losing by one's own follyâ€™: cp. Ar. Eccl. 750Î¿á½ Î³á½°Ï Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼Î¼á½¸Î½ á¼±Î´Ïá¿¶Ï„Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï†ÎµÎ¹Î´Ï‰Î»á½·Î±Î½ | Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼”Ï€Î¿Ï‚ Î¿á½•Ï„Ï‰Ï‚ á¼€Î½Î¿á½µÏ„Ï‰Ï‚ á¼ÎºÎ²Î±Î»á¿¶.
